40.14 km | mass=6.8{{E|16}} kg | rotation={{Convert|11.4969|h|d|abbr=on|lk=on}} | spectral_type=[[M-type asteroid|M]] | abs_magnitude=9.69 | albedo={{val|0.1459|0.007}}
0.1459 }} '''Austria''' ([[minor planet designation]]: '''136 Austria''') is a [[main-belt]] [[asteroid]] that was found by the prolific asteroid discoverer [[Johann Palisa]] on 18 March 1874, from the [[Austrian Naval Observatory]] in [[Pula|Pola]], [[Istria County|Istria]]. It was his first asteroid discovery and was given the Latin name of his [[Austria-Hungary|homeland]]. Based upon its spectrum, it is classified as an [[M-type asteroid|M-type spectrum]], although Clark et al. (1994) suggest it may be more like an [[S-type asteroid]]. It shows almost no absorption features in the near infrared, which may indicate an iron or [[enstatite chondrite]] surface composition. A weak hydration feature was detected in 2006. [[Photometry (astronomy)|Photometric]] observations of this asteroid at the [[European Southern Observatory]] in 1981 gave a [[light curve]] with a period of 11.5 ± 0.1 hours and a brightness variation of 0.40 in [[Magnitude (astronomy)|magnitude]]. As of 2013, the estimated rotation period is 11.4969 hours. == References == {{Reflist|refs= {{cite web |type = 2018-02-26 last obs. |title = JPL Small-Body Database Browser: 136 Austria |url = https://ssd.jpl.nasa.gov/sbdb.cgi?sstr=2000136 |publisher = [[Jet Propulsion Laboratory]] |accessdate = 29 May 2018}} {{cite web |title = 136 Austria |work = Minor Planet Center |url = https://www.minorplanetcenter.net/db_search/show_object?object_id=136 |accessdate = 29 May 2018}} {{cite web |title = Asteroid 136 Austria |work = Small Bodies Data Ferret |url = https://sbntools.psi.edu/ferret/SimpleSearch/results.action?targetName=136+Austria |accessdate = 29 May 2018}} {{Citation | last1 = Albrecht | first1 = R. | last2 = Maitzen | first2 = H.-M. | last3 = Schnell | first3 = A. | display-authors = 1 | title = Early asteroid research in Austria | work = Planetary and Space Science | volume = 49 | issue = 8 | pages = 777–779 |date=July 2001 | doi = 10.1016/S0032-0633(01)00027-7 | bibcode = 2001P&SS...49..777A | postscript= . }} {{Citation | last1 = Schober | first1 = H. J. | title = Rotation periods and lightcurves of the asteroids 136 Austria and 238 Hypatia | work = Astronomy and Astrophysics | volume = 117 | issue = 2 | pages = 362–364 |date=January 1983 | bibcode = 1983A&A...117..362S | postscript= . }} {{Citation |last1=Hardersen |first1=Paul S. |last2=Gaffey |first2=Michael J. |last3=Abell |first3=Paul A. |title=Near-IR spectral evidence for the presence of iron-poor orthopyroxenes on the surfaces of six M-type asteroids |work=Icarus |volume=175 |issue=1 |pages=141–158 |date=January 1983 |doi=10.1016/j.icarus.2004.10.017 |bibcode=2005Icar..175..141H |url= |postscript=. }} {{Citation | last1 = Clark | first1 = B. E. | last2 = Bell | first2 = J. F. | last3 = O'Connor | first3 = D. J. | last4 = Fanale | first4 = F. P. | display-authors = 1 | title = Infrared Spectral Observations of Smaller (50 km) Main Belt S, K, and M Type Asteroids | work = Abstracts of the 25th Lunar and Planetary Science Conference, held in Houston, TX, 14–18 March 1994 | pages = 265–266 |date=March 1994 | bibcode = 1994LPI....25..265C | postscript= . }} {{Citation | last = Behrend | first = Raoul | title = Courbes de rotation d'astéroïdes et de comètes | publisher = [[Observatoire de Genève]] | language = French | url = http://obswww.unige.ch/~behrend/page_cou.html | accessdate = 2013-03-30 }} }} == External links == * {{AstDys|136}} * {{JPL small body}} {{Minor planets navigator|135 Hertha|number=136|137 Meliboea}} {{Small Solar System bodies}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Austria}} [[Category:Background asteroids|000136]] [[Category:Numbered minor planets|000136]] [[Category:Discoveries by Johann Palisa]] [[Category:Minor planets named for places]] [[Category:Named minor planets]] [[Category:M-type asteroids (Tholen)|000136]] [[Category:Xe-type asteroids (SMASS)|000136]] [[Category:Astronomical objects discovered in 1874|18740318]] {{beltasteroid-stub}}

{{coord|53.2440|-2.9298|display=inline|name=A494 road (northeastern end)}}{{cite web |url=https://maps.google.co.uk/maps?ll=53.24403,-2.929396&spn=0.000454,0.001212&t=h&z=20&layer=c&cbll=53.24403,-2.929396&panoid=JrO3qdJTKpZgZSMZegK9hA&cbp=12,254.29,,0,15.93 |title=M56, England, United Kingdom |date=July 2012 |work= |publisher=[[Google]] |accessdate=14 April 2013}} |direction_b= Southwest |terminus_b = [[Dolgellau]]

[[Bala, Gwynedd|Bala]] }} The '''A494''' is a [[trunk road]] in [[Wales]]. The route, which is officially known as the '''Dolgellau to South of Birkenhead Trunk Road''', runs between the terminus of the [[M56 motorway]] between [[Mollington, Cheshire|Mollington]] and [[Capenhurst]] and the [[A470 road|A470]] at [[Dolgellau]], [[Gwynedd]]. Its northern sections remain among the busiest roads in Wales.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/wales/7687340.stm|title=Politicians ponder future of A494 |publisher=[[BBC NEWS]]|date=24 October 2008|accessdate=3 July 2015}} ==History== The original routes into North Wales meant using [[Ford (crossing)|ford]]s when the Dee estuary was at low tide north west of [[Chester]]. But when the river was [[River Dee, Wales#Canalised section|canalised in the 1730s]] several new coach roads were laid out through [[Sealand, Flintshire|Sealand]], [[Shotton, Flintshire|Shotton]] and [[Queensferry, Flintshire|Queensferry]]. These were built by the Dee Company under the River Dee Act of 1743 to serve the hand-operated ferries which had replaced the fords.http://www.cpat.org.uk/projects/longer/ports/ports.htm By 1861 the ferry at Shotton was steam operated, with an engine house on the Queensferry side. In 1897 the ferry was replaced by an innovative [[retractable bridge]] because of increasing mechanised transport.{{cite web|url=http://www.british-history.ac.uk/report.aspx?compid=57309|title=ROADS AND ROAD TRANSPORT|publisher=British History Online|date=2009-09-27}}{{cite web|url=http://www.cpat.org.uk/projects/longer/ports/ports.htm|title= Ports and Harbours in North-east Wales|publisher=The Clwyd-Powys Archaeological Trust|date=2009-09-27}} The Queen Victoria Jubilee Toll Bridge, which was built from iron, stone and wood, could retract its middle sections for the passage of river traffic.{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-wales-north-east-wales-25444392|title=Connah's Quay dock revival and tall ships funding bid|publisher=[[BBC NEWS]]|date=29 December 2013}} However, by the early 1920s, increasing numbers of motor vehicles and the narrowness of the bridge made the area notorious for traffic congestion. These issues prompted its replacement. [[File:Stone Abutment for the Old Queensferry Bridge - geograph.org.uk - 410716.jpg|thumb|left|200px|The stone abutment for the Queensferry bridge]] In 1926 a rolling [[bascule bridge]], called the New Jubilee Bridge, was opened by the [[Department for Transport|Ministry of Transport]] for the newly named A494. Its design allowed river traffic to use the wharfs at [[Saltney]]. The original bridge was demolished although the stone abutments can still be seen today. The steel bridge remained the sole road crossing at Queensferry until the late 1950s. But its size and design had limitations, a news report at the time stated it "is barely wide enough for two lines of vehicles, and five-mile traffic jams are normal".[http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,869049,00.html Time Magazine] In the late 1960s, the A494 was upgraded to a dual carriageway from Drome corner. The original route through Shotton and Queensferry was bypassed after a wider fixed-arched bridge was constructed across the River Dee. This was facilitated by reduction of larger river traffic following the closure of the sea-going wharfs at Saltney. The present route had remained unchanged until a lane upgrade in 2004. ==Queensferry to Ewloe== This section forms part of the [[North Wales]] coast route between [[Holyhead]] and the [[M56 motorway]]. The section of the A494 north of the [[River Dee, Wales|River Dee]] was upgraded to 4-lanes plus hard shoulders in each direction in 2004 as part of a wider scheme, which upgraded the [[A550 road|A550]] as well, although not all of the lanes on the A494 have been opened. The next stage of the scheme was to widen a {{convert|2.5|mi|km|adj=on}} stretch of the A494 from the River Dee up Aston Hill to the ''[[Ewloe]] Interchange'', the junction of the [[A55 road|A55]] and A494, to 3 and 4-lane plus hard shoulder standard. In April 2006, local residents living at Aston Hill, part of the proposed route, began a campaign to oppose any further widening of the A494.{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/wales/north_east/6246209.stm | work=BBC News | title=Protest over road-widening plans | date=2007-01-10 | accessdate=2010-04-23}} After 15 months, protesters' high-profile message had garnered more than 2300 individual letters and numerous petitions rejecting the proposals.[http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=3014612 Mass protest call by A494 campaigners - Evening Leader]{{Dead link|date=September 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} A Planning Inquiry was held in September - October 2007. In March 2008 the proposals (in entirety) were ordered to be scrapped by the Ieuan Wyn Jones, Deputy First Minister, responsible for Transport at the Welsh Assembly.
"In reaching my decision I have taken account of the concerns raised by the inspector that the overall size of the scheme would have a significant impact on the landscape and would affect walking and cycling routes. I have also noted [the planning inspector's] remarks that while he considers that this section of the A494 will need some form of improvement in the foreseeable future, he considers that the scale of the scheme as originally proposed is greater than required." [[Ieuan Wyn Jones|Deputy First Minister Ieuan Wyn Jones]][http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/wales/7315973.stm Welsh Minister rejects plans]
This part of the A494 will remain a two-lane dual carriageway and the speed limit will be {{convert|50|mi/h|km/h|abbr=on}}. The decision has left a question mark over the future of the remaining upgrade at ''Ewloe Interchange''. Resentment also remains within the Aston Hill community as thirty households were evicted from their homes earlier in the scheme. These houses were earmarked to be demolished to make way for the road-widening works.{{Cite web |url=http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news/Evicted-man-slams-Welsh-Assembly.3925046.jp |title=Evicted man slams Welsh Assembly over scrapped A494 plans - Evening Leader |access-date=16 June 2008 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080513141554/http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news/Evicted-man-slams-Welsh-Assembly.3925046.jp |archive-date=13 May 2008 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }} No decision has been made about the future of these properties. ==Ewloe to Corwen== Just past Ewloe interchange the [[A55 road|A55]] converges with the A494. At this point the dual carriageway becomes the A55 and the A494 diverges onto a single-carriageway trunk road. This section is approximately {{convert|25|mi}} in length. It is largely national speed limit with exceptions through urbanised areas. The A494, which follows a largely unchanged historic route, passes [[Mold, Flintshire|Mold]] through the [[Clwydian Range|Clwydian Mountains]], down to [[Ruthin]] and on to the market town of [[Corwen]]. Although it follows the traditional coach route, work has been undertaken over many decades to improve various sections of this road. For instance a bypass was completed in 1999 to allow traffic to avoid Mold's town centre. Likewise a dangerous road junction for [[Moel Famau]], just outside [[Loggerheads, Denbighshire|Loggerheads]], that was on a bend and blind brow has now been completely bypassed. The A494 enters [[Ruthin]] by traversing the steep side of the Vale of Clwyd. Beyond the town, it heads south through several small villages. Beside the road for much of the way is the disused [[Denbigh, Ruthin and Corwen Railway|Ruthin to Corwen Railway line]]. The A494, up to this point, often remains [[Traffic congestion|congestion]]-free as a lot of traffic follows the parallel shorter [[A5104 road|A5104]] between the A55 and Corwen around Llantysilio Mountain. The A494 meets the [[A5 road (Great Britain)|A5 trunk road]] at a [[T-junction]] just outside Corwen. It now makes a short {{convert|1.5|mi}} [[Concurrency (road)|concurrency]] with the A5 to Druid. ==Druid to Dolgellau== [[File:Bala High Street.jpg|thumb|200px|The A494 through the centre of [[Bala, Gwynedd|Bala]], [[Gwynedd]].]] The A494 diverges from the concurrency with the A5 at the road junction at Druid, [[Denbighshire]]. It then heads south west for {{convert|27|mi}} to [[Dolgellau]], [[Gwynedd]]. This section of the A494 remains single carriageway. It has variable speed limits. [[North Wales Police]] regularly conduct traffic operations on this road.[http://www.denbighshirefreepress.co.uk/news/Police-are-driving-bikers-away.5200518.jp Police are driving bikers 'away' from North Wales]{{dead link|date=September 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} accessdate=2009-05-13 The A494 enters the [[Snowdonia National Park]] just outside the market town of [[Bala, Gwynedd|Bala]]. It then runs adjacent to [[Bala Lake]] ({{lang-cy|Llyn Tegid}}) for {{convert|4|mi}} and past [[Aran Fawddwy]]. Beyond the southwest end of the lake, at the summit of the pass at Pant Gwyn, the A494 enters a long steeply graded valley that follows the River Wnion ({{lang-cy|Afon Wnion}}) to [[Dolgellau]]. Again a [[Ruabon to Barmouth Line|former railway]] also runs parallel with the road. The remains of the line can be seen in places. The A494 terminates at a T-junction with the [[A470 road|A470]] just outside the [[market town]] of Dolgellau beneath [[Cadair Idris]]. ==See also== * [[Trunk roads in Wales]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==Sources== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20061009151144/http://www.cbrd.co.uk/futures/junction/a5117.shtml Motorways UK] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20120205002712/http://www.highways.gov.uk/roads/projects/5018.aspx Highways Agency] *[http://www.cpat.org.uk/projects/longer/ports/ports.htm Aston Hill Project] {{commons category|A494 road (Wales)}} {{GeoGroupTemplate}} {{GB A road zone 4}} {{Motorways and Trunk Roads in Wales|state=collapsed}} {{coord|52.9705|-3.4551|dim:50000_region:GB|display=title|name=A494 road}} {{DEFAULTSORT:4-0494}} [[Category:Roads in Denbighshire]] [[Category:Roads in Flintshire]] [[Category:Roads in Gwynedd|494]]

[[File:Abiotic components.svg|thumb|Abiotic factors are non living components found in an ecosystem which influence living things (biotic factors).]] {{pp-pc1|small=yes}} In [[biology]] and [[ecology]], '''abiotic components''' or '''abiotic factors''' are non-living chemical and [[Physical property|physical]] parts of the [[Natural environment|environment]] that affect living [[organism]]s and the functioning of [[ecosystem]]s. Abiotic factors and the phenomena associated with them underpin all biology.
Abiotic components include physical conditions and non-living [[Resource (biology)|resources]] that affect living organisms in terms of [[Developmental biology|growth]], [[Maintenance of an organism|maintenance]], and [[reproduction]]. Resources are distinguished as substances or objects in the environment required by one organism and consumed or otherwise made unavailable for use by other organisms.<ref>Ricklefs, R.E. 2005. ''The Economy of Nature, 6th edition''. WH Freeman, USA.</ref><ref>Chapin, F.S. III, H.A. Mooney, M.C. Chapin, and P. Matson. 2011. Principles of terrestrial ecosystem ecology. Springer, New York.</ref> [[File:Abiotic Factors.tif|thumb|These are different settings on earth that are abiotic factors, which mean they are not living organisms, that contribute to the earth in many different ways.]] Component degradation of a substance occurs by [[chemical process|chemical]] or [[Physical change|physical process]]es, e.g. [[hydrolysis]]. All non-living components of an ecosystem, such as atmospheric conditions and water resources, are called abiotic components.<ref>Water Quality Vocabulary. ISO 6107-6:1994.</ref>
== Examples == In biology, abiotic factors can include water, light, radiation, temperature, [[humidity]], [[atmosphere]], and soil. The macroscopic climate often influences each of the above. Pressure and sound waves may also be considered in the context of marine or sub-terrestrial environments.<ref name=EoEarth>{{cite web|url=http://www.eoearth.org/article/Abiotic_factor?topic=49461 |title=Abiotic factor |publisher=National Council for Science and the Environment |year=2010 |last=Hogan |first=C. Benito |location=Washington, D.C. |work=Encyclopedia of Earth |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130608071757/http://www.eoearth.org/article/Abiotic_factor?topic=49461 |archivedate=2013-06-08 }}</ref> Abiotic factors in ocean environments also include aerial exposure, substrate, water clarity, solar energy and tides.<ref name="National Geographic Education">{{cite web |url=https://media.nationalgeographic.org/assets/file/Ocean_Abiotic_Factors_1.pdf |title=Ocean Abiotic Factors |publisher=National Geographic Society |year=2011}}</ref> Consider the differences in the mechanics of [[C3 carbon fixation|C3]], [[C4 carbon fixation|C4]], and [[Crassulacean acid metabolism|CAM]] plants in regulating the influx of [[carbon dioxide]] to the [[Calvin-Benson Cycle]] in relation to their abiotic stressors. C3 plants have no mechanisms to manage [[photorespiration]], whereas C4 and CAM plants utilize a separate [[PEP Carboxylase]] enzyme to prevent photorespiration, thus increasing the yield of photosynthetic processes in certain high energy environments.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Wang|first1=Chuali|last2=Guo|first2=Longyun|last3=Li|first3=Yixue|last4=Wang|first4=Zhuo|title=Systematic Comparison of C3 and C4 Plants Based on Metabolic Network Analysis|journal=BMC Systems Biology|date=2012|volume=6|issue=59|doi=10.1186/1752-0509-6-S2-S9}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Rubisco and C4 Plants|url=http://www.rsc.org/learn-chemistry/content/filerepository/CMP/00/001/066/Rubisco%20and%20C4%20plants.pdf?v=1353967268963|website=RSC: Advancing the Chemical Sciences|publisher=RSC}}</ref>
Many [[Archea]] require very high temperatures, pressures or unusual concentrations of chemical substances such as sulfur; this is due to their specialization into extreme conditions. In addition, fungi have also evolved to survive at the temperature, the humidity, and stability of their environment.<ref name=UWC>{{cite web|url=http://www.botany.uwc.ac.za/sci_ed/grade10/ecology/abiotic/abiot.htm |title=Abiotic Components |publisher=Department of Biodiversity and Conservation Biology, [[University of the Western Cape]] |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20050425160041/http://www.botany.uwc.ac.za/SCI_ED/grade10/ecology/abiotic/abiot.htm |archivedate=2005-04-25 }}</ref>
For example, there is a significant difference in access in both water and humidity between [[temperate rain forest]]s and [[desert]]s. This difference in water availability causes a diversity in the types of plants and animals that survive in these areas. These differences in abiotic components alter the species present both by creating boundaries of what species can survive within the environment, as well as influencing competition between two species. Abiotic factors such as salinity can give one species a competitive advantage over another, creating pressures that lead to speciation and alteration of a species to and from generalist and specialist competitors.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Dunson|first=William A.|date=November 1991|title=The Role of Abiotic Factors in Community Organization|url=https://www.jstor.org.ezp1.lib.umn.edu/stable/pdf/2462508.pdf|journal=The American Naturalist|volume=138 |issue=5|pages=1067–1091|doi=10.1086/285270}}</ref>
== See also == {{Wikiquote}} * [[Biotic component]], a living part of an ecosystem that affects and shapes it. * [[Abiogenesis]], the gradual process of increasing complexity of non-living into living matter. * [[Nitrogen cycle]] * [[Phosphorus cycle]]
== References == {{reflist}}
{{Modelling ecosystems}}
[[Category:Environmental science]]

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=August 2014}} '''Ary-Mas''' ({{lang-ru|Ары-Мас}}) is a forest in [[Russia]], [[Krasnoyarsk Krai]], southern part of [[Taymyr Peninsula]], southern bank of [[Novaya River]]. Ary-Mas comes from the [[Dolgan language]] and means "forest island".
Considered to be the northernmost [[forest]] of the world although [[Lukunsky grove]] to the east from it extends 6 kilometres further north. Though, while Lukunsky grove is northernmost rim of larger forest massif, Ary-Mas is a forest island separated from the nearest forest by approximately 200 kilometres wide zone of [[tundra]].
==Climate== Vegetation period is approximately 100 days long. Winter here lasts from late September to early October to June, minimum temperatures often fall below -35 – -45 °C, wind speed in winter often exceeds 50 m/s.<ref>http://www.taimyrsky.ru/index.htm State Nature Biosphere Reserve "Taymyrsky", accessed on 6 February 2010.</ref>
Polar day lasts from the late June to early August, median temperature in July is 12 °C, often up to 30 °C.
[[Permafrost]] in summer thaws 0.3 – 2 metres deep. Thickness of permafrost here is approximately 200 metres.
==Biodiversity== The only tree-form species of Ary-Mas is [[Dahurian larch]] (''Larix gmelinii'' (Rupr.) Rupr.)), but in total in Ary-Mas there have been found 306 species of plants, 90 species of birds, 20 species of mammals.
Dahurian larch grows sparsely, separate trees grow up to 5 – 7 metres tall.
==Conservation and scientific investigations== Ary-Mas is a protected territory with area 156,11 km2. It forms a part of [[Taymyr Nature Reserve|Taymyr State Nature Biosphere Reserve]] and is protected since 1979.
Constant investigations of Dahurian larch started in 1969 and have continued since then. Current scientific studies are led by the Taymyr State Nature Biosphere Reserve and major part of results are compiled in yearly nature reports.
==References== <references/>
==External links== * [http://www.wondermondo.com/Countries/E/RUS/Krasnoyarsk/AryMas.htm Wondermondo, Ary-Mas - the northern forest] * [http://www.taimyrsky.ru/index.htm State Nature Biosphere Reserve "Taymyrsky"]
{{coord|72|28|N|102|15|E|type:landmark|display=title}}
[[Category:Forests of Russia]] [[Category:Extreme points of Earth]]

{{For|the French Navy officer|Jacques Bedout}} {{Infobox terrestrial impact site | name = Bedout | other_name = | photo = | photo_size = | photo_alt = | photo_caption = | map = Western Australia | map_alt = | map_caption = Location of Bedout offshore Western Australia | map_size = | location = [[Canning Basin]] | label = | label_position = | coordinates = {{coord|18|S|119|E|region:AU-WA_type:landmark_scale:10000000|display=inline,title}} | coordinates_ref = | confidence = Possible | diameter = {{convert|30|km|mi|abbr=on}} | depth = | rise = | imp_size = | age = 250.1 ± 4.5 Ma
[[Permian-Triassic boundary]] | exposed = No | drilled = Yes | bolide = | translation = | language = | pronunciation = | topo = | access = | country = {{AUS}} | state = [[Indian Ocean]] | province = | district = | municipality = }} '''Bedout''' {{IPAc-en|b|ᵻ|ˈ|d|uː}}, or more specifically the '''Bedout High''', is a [[geological]] and [[geophysical]] feature centered about 250 km off the northwestern coast of [[Australia]] in the [[Canning Basin|Canning]] and overlying [[Roebuck Basin|Roebuck]] basins. Although not obvious from sea floor topography, it is a roughly circular area about 30 km in diameter where older rocks have been uplifted as much as 4 km towards the surface.Gorter J.D. 1996. Speculation on the origin of the Bedout high - a large, circular structure of pre-Mesozoic age in the offshore Canning Basin, Western Australia. PESA News, October/November 1996, p. 32-34. The Bedout High was penetrated by two petroleum exploration wells (Bedout-1, Lagrange-1) in the 1970s and 1980s. It is named after nearby [[Bedout Island]]. == Impact hypothesis == In 1996 Australian [[geologist]] John Gorter first suggested that the Bedout High might mark the centre of a very large buried [[impact crater]] up to 250 km in diameter, based mainly on its internal geological structure as revealed on a single [[Reflection seismology|seismic]] survey line, and suggested that it may be of near end [[Permian]] age, based on the reported age of volcanic rocks in Lagrange-1.Gorter J.D. 1998. The petroleum potential of Australian Phanerozoic impact structures. The APPEA Journal 38, 159-187. The impact hypothesis was developed further by Luanne Becker ([[University of California]]) and coworkers who claimed to have confirmed that the supposed volcanic rocks in the petroleum wells are actually impact melt [[breccia]] showing evidence of [[shock metamorphism]], and re-dated these rocks at 250.1 ± 4.5 [[Annum|Ma]].Becker L., Poreda R.J., Basu A.R., Pope K.O., Harrison T.M., Nicholson C. & Iasky R. 2004. Bedout: A possible end-Permian impact crater offshore of northwestern Australia. Science 304, 1469-1476. [http://www.sciencemag.org/cgi/content/abstract/1093925 Abstract] The new age is essentially coincident with the [[Permian]]-[[Triassic]] boundary and associated [[Permian-Triassic extinction event|extinction event]], and Becker speculates that there is a likely connection. It was subsequently reported, based on very limited preliminary data, that the impact hypothesis is further supported by [[chromium]] [[isotope]] evidence for the presence of extraterrestrial material.Becker L., Shukolyukov A., Macassic C., Lugmair G. & Poreda R. 2006. Extraterrestrial Chromium at the Graphite Peak P/Tr boundary and in the Bedout Impact Melt Breccia. Lunar and Planetary Science XXXVII (2006), abstract # 2321.[http://www.lpi.usra.edu/meetings/lpsc2006/pdf/2321.pdf PDF] == Rebuttals to the impact hypothesis == The Bedout impact hypothesis has not been widely supported by impact cratering specialists. Specific counter claims include: # The alleged impact melt breccia actually has the characteristics of a volcanic [[basalt]], in part altered by contact with sea water and [[metamorphism]] due to its deep burial, and the evidence for shock metamorphism is likely mistaken.Glikson A. 2004. Comment on ‘‘Bedout: A possible end-Permian impact crater offshore of northwestern Australia’’. Science 306, 613b.[http://www.sciencemag.org/cgi/reprint/306/5696/613b.pdf PDF]Glikson A. 2004. Bedout basement rise, offshore northwestern Australia: evidence of an unshocked mafic volcanic hyaloclastite volcanic breccia. Eos Trans. AGU, 85(47), Fall Meet. Suppl., Abstract B33C-0269. [http://www.agu.org/cgi-bin/SFgate/SFgate?&listenv=table&multiple=1&range=1&directget=1&application=fm04&database=%2Fdata%2Fepubs%2Fwais%2Findexes%2Ffm04%2Ffm04&maxhits=200&=B33C-0269 Abstract] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070927192927/http://www.agu.org/cgi-bin/SFgate/SFgate?&listenv=table&multiple=1&range=1&directget=1&application=fm04&database=%2Fdata%2Fepubs%2Fwais%2Findexes%2Ffm04%2Ffm04&maxhits=200&=B33C-0269 |date=2007-09-27 }} # A crater of the purported size would have produced a widespread layer of ejecta, but no such eject is evident at the nearest Permian-Triassic boundary sites in Australia.Wignall P., Thomas B., Willink R., Watling J., Becker L., Poreda R.J. & Pope K.O. 2004. Is Bedout an impact crater? Take 1. Science 306, 609-610. # The presented evidence for impact fails to meet established standards, and the dating methodology is flawed.Renne P.R., Melosh H.J., Farley K.A., Reimold W.U., Koeberl C., Rampino M.R., Kelley S.P., Ivanov B.A., Becker L., Poreda R.J., Basu A.R., Pope K.O., Harrison T.M., Nicholson C. & Iasky R. 2004. Is Bedout an impact crater? Take 2. Science 306, 610-612. # A detailed re-evaluation of the geophysical data indicates that the evidence is not consistent with the expected properties of a giant impact crater, but rather the Bedout High was likely the result of episodes of continental rifting.Müller R.D., Goncharov A. & Kristi A. 2005. Geophysical evaluation of the enigmatic Bedout basement high, offshore northwest Australia. Earth and Planetary Science Letters 237, 265-284. == See also == {{portal|Geology|Prehistory of Oceania}} * [[List of unconfirmed impact craters on Earth]] == References == {{reflist}} == External links == * [http://records.viu.ca/~earles/bedout-jun04.htm Stephen Earle, "Double jeopardy at the end of the Permian - new evidence for a large impact"] [[Category:Geology of Western Australia]] [[Category:Possible impact craters on Earth]] [[Category:Impact craters of Australia]] [[Category:Permian impact craters]] [[Category:Triassic impact craters]] [[Category:Permian Australia]] [[Category:Triassic Australia]] [[Category:Geography of the Indian Ocean]] [[Category:Permian–Triassic extinction event]]

revision.text:
[[Image:Regiuni de dezvoltare.svg|thumb|right|350px|Map of the development regions]] {{Politics of Romania}} The '''development regions of Romania''' (Romanian ''Regiunile de dezvoltare ale României'') refer to the eight regional divisions created in [[Romania]] in 1998 in order to better co-ordinate regional development as Romania progressed towards accession to the [[European Union]]. The development regions correspond to [[Nomenclature of Territorial Units for Statistics|NUTS II]]-level divisions in European Union member states. Despite becoming increasingly significant in regional development projects, Romania's development regions do not actually have an administrative status and do not have a legislative or executive council or government. Rather, they serve a function for allocating European Union [[PHARE]] funds for regional development, as well as for collection of regional statistics. They also co-ordinate a range of regional development projects and became members of the [[Committee of the Regions]] when Romania joined the EU on January 1, 2007. ==List== There are 8 development regions in Romania, which (with the exception of București-Ilfov) are named by their geographical position in the country: *RO1 – [[Macroregiune]]a 1: **[[Nord-Vest (development region)|Nord-Vest]] – RO11; 6 counties; 2,600,132 inhabitants; {{convert|34159|km2|sqmi|abbr=on}} **[[Centru (development region)|Centru]] – RO12; 6 counties; 2,360,805 inhabitants; {{convert|34082|km2|sqmi|abbr=on}} *RO2 – Macroregiunea 2: **[[Nord-Est (development region)|Nord-Est]] – RO21; 6 counties; 3,302,217 inhabitants; {{convert|36850|km2|sqmi|abbr=on}} **[[Sud-Est (development region)|Sud-Est]] – RO22; 6 counties; 2,545,923 inhabitants; {{convert|35762|km2|sqmi|abbr=on}} *RO3 – Macroregiunea 3: **[[Sud (development region)|Sud - Muntenia]] – RO31; 7 counties; 3,136,446 inhabitants; {{convert|34489|km2|sqmi|abbr=on}} **[[București-Ilfov (development region)|București - Ilfov]] – RO32; 1 county and Bucharest; 2,272,163 inhabitants; {{convert|1811|km2|sqmi|abbr=on}} *RO4 – Macroregiunea 4: **[[Sud-Vest (development region)|Sud-Vest Oltenia]] – RO41; 5 counties; 2,075,642 inhabitants; {{convert|29212|km2|sqmi|abbr=on}} **[[Vest (development region)|Vest]] – RO42; 4 counties; 1,828,313 inhabitants; {{convert|32028|km2|sqmi|abbr=on}} ==Economy== {| class="wikitable sortable" |+[[Gross domestic product]] (GDP) as reported by [[Eurostat]] ! !colspan=5 style="text-align:center|2006 !colspan=5 style="text-align:center|2016http://ec.europa.eu/eurostat/documents/2995521/8700651/1-28022018-BP-EN/15f5fd90-ce8b-4927-9a3b-07dc255dc42a |- ![[Administrative divisions of Romania|Region]]
