'''Fountaineer''' is a [[portmanteau]] of '''"[[Fountain]]"''' and '''"[[Engineer]]"''' - [[Hydraulic engineer]].
'''Fountaineer (band)''' are an indie-rock band from Bendigo, Australia.
Fountaineer describes one who designs, explores, or is passionate about fountains and their design, operation, and use.
==Fountaineers== Notable fountaineers include: * [[André Le Nôtre]]: [[Gardens of Versailles]]; others. * [[Lawrence Halprin]]: [[Keller Fountain Park]]; [[Freeway Park]]; [[Franklin Delano Roosevelt Memorial]]; others. * [[Dan Euser]]: [[Dundas Square]]; proposed [[World Trade Center (1973–2001)|World Trade Center]] memorial fountains ''[world's largest human-made waterfall]'' * [[Ninjalicious|Jeff Chapman]]: fountaineering as subject. * [[Jean Tinguely]] + [[Niki de Saint Phalle]]: [[Stravinsky Fountain]]; others.. * [[WET Design]]: [[Fountain of Nations]]; [[Salt Lake 2002 Olympic Cauldron Park]]; [[Bellagio (hotel and casino)#Fountains of Bellagio|Fountains of Bellagio]]; others.
==See also== *[[Fountain]]s *[[Fountain (Duchamp)]] *[[Fountains in Paris]] *[[List of fountains in Rome]] *[[:Category:Fountains|Category: Fountains]] *[[:Category:Outdoor sculptures|Category: Outdoor sculptures]]
==References== *Liz Clayton "Fountaineering", ''[[Spacing (magazine)|Spacing]]'', special issue on Water, Summer 2007, pp42–43 *[http://wiki.joshuajamesslone.name/tiki-index.php?page=Jeff%20Chapman Jeff Chapman, The man behind YIP? and Infiltration zines, urban explorer, and fountaineer.]
[[Category:Fountains]] [[Category:Sculptors]] [[Category:Landscape or garden designers]] [[Category:Landscape architecture]] [[Category:Hydraulic engineers]]
{{architecture-stub}}

[[File:Zealandia-Continent map en.svg|right|thumb|upright=1.35|New Zealand and [[New Caledonia]] represent the visible part of a portion of [[continental crust]], usually referred to as Zealandia. The rest of Zealandia includes the [[Challenger Plateau]] and [[Lord Howe Rise]], which stretch from Northwest of New Zealand almost to Northern Australia, and the [[Campbell Plateau]] and [[Chatham Rise]], to the southeast of New Zealand.]] The [[geology]] of [[New Zealand]] is noted for its [[volcanic]] activity, [[earthquake]]s and [[geothermal]] [[Geothermal areas in New Zealand|areas]] because of its position on the boundary of the [[Australian Plate]] and [[Pacific Plate]]s. New Zealand is part of [[Zealandia]], a [[microcontinent]] nearly half the size of Australia that broke away from the [[Gondwana]]n supercontinent about 83 million years ago.<ref>{{Cite journal | last1 = Wallis | first1 = G. P. | last2 = Trewick | first2 = S. A. | doi = 10.1111/j.1365-294X.2009.04294.x | title = New Zealand phylogeography: evolution on a small continent | journal = Molecular Ecology | volume = 18 | issue = 17 | pages = 3548–3580 | year = 2009 | pmid = 19674312| pmc = }}</ref> New Zealands early separation from other landmasses and subsequant evolution has created a unquie [[fossil]] record and modern [[Environment of New Zealand|ecology]].
New Zealand's geology can be simplified into three phases. First the [[basement rock|basement rocks]] of New Zealand formed. These rocks were once part of the super-continent of Gondwana, along with [[South America]], [[Africa]], [[Madagascar]], [[India]], [[Antarctica]] and [[Australia]]. The rocks that now form the, mostly submerged, continent of Zealandia were then nestled between Eastern Australia and [[Western Antarctica]].<ref>[http://www.teara.govt.nz/EarthSeaAndSky/Geology/GeologyOverview/3/ENZ-Resources/Standard/1/en#breadcrumbtop New Zealand within Gondwana] from Te Ara: The Encyclopedia of New Zealand</ref> Secondly New Zealand drifted away from Gondwana and many [[sedimentary basins]] formed, which later became the [[sedimentary rock]]s covering the geological basement. The final phase is represented by the uplift of the [[Southern Alps]] and the eruptions of the [[Taupo Volcanic Zone]].<ref>{{cite web |url= https://www.geotrips.org.nz/downloads/Ballance_NZ_Geology-V2.pdf |title= New Zealand Geology: an illustrated guide |website= www.geotrips.org.nz}}</ref>
==Basement rocks (Cambrian-Cretaceous)== {{See also|Stratigraphy of New Zealand}} [[File:New Zealand geology map with key.jpg|thumb|upright=1.5]]
New Zealand's [[basement rocks]] range in age from mid-[[Cambrian]] in north-west [[Nelson, New Zealand|Nelson]] to [[Cretaceous]] near [[Kaikoura]]. These rocks were formed in a [[Ocean|marine]] environment before New Zealand separated from Gondwana. They are divided into the "Western Province", consisting mainly of [[greywacke]], [[granite]] and [[gneiss]], and an "Eastern Province", consisting mainly of [[greywacke]] and [[schist]].<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Mortimer |first1=N |date=2004 |title=New Zealand's geological foundations. |url=https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S1342937X05703245 |journal=Gondwana Research |volume=7 |issue=1 |pages=261-272 |doi= |access-date= }}</ref> The provinces are further divided into [[terranes]] – large slices of crust with different geological histories that have been brought together by tectonic activity ([[subduction]] and [[strike-slip faulting]]) to form New Zealand.
The Western Province is older than the Eastern Province and outcrops along the west coast of the South Island from [[Nelson, New Zealand|Nelson]] to [[Fiordland]]. The Western Province is divided into the [[Buller Terrane|Buller]] and [[Takaka Terrane|Takaka]] terranes which formed in mid-Cambrian to [[Devonian]] time (510–400 Ma). This includes New Zealand's oldest rocks, [[trilobite]] containing greywacke, which are found in the [[Cobb River, New Zealand|Cobb Valley]] in north-west Nelson.<ref name="Mortimer2004">{{cite journal|last1=Mortimer|first1=N.|title=New Zealand's Geological Foundations|journal=Gondwana Research|volume=7|issue=1|year=2004|pages=261–272|issn=1342937X|doi=10.1016/S1342-937X(05)70324-5}}</ref>
Large sections of the of Western Province have been intruded by [[plutonic]] rocks or [[metamorphism|metamorphosed]] to gneiss. These plutonic basement rocks are subdivided into the [[Hohonu Batholith|Hohonu]], [[Karamea Batholith|Karamea]], [[Median Batholith|Median]] and [[Paparoa Batholith|Paparoa]] [[batholith]]s.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://data.gns.cri.nz/ |title= New Zealand Stratigraphic Lexicon |last= |first= |date=|website= |publisher=GNS Science |access-date=|quote=}}</ref> These rocks form the foundations beneath offshore [[Taranaki]], and much of the [[West Coast (New Zealand)|West Coast]], [[Buller District|Buller]], north-west [[Nelson, New Zealand|Nelson]], [[Fiordland]] and [[Stewart Island]]. Most of these plutonic rocks were formed in [[Devonian]]-[[Carboniferous]] time (380–335 Ma) and [[Jurassic]]-[[Cretaceous]] time (155–100 Ma). The Median Batholith represents a long-lived batholith dividing the Western and Eastern Provinces. Before Zealandia's separation from [[Gondwana]] it stretched from [[Queensland]], through what is now New Zealand, into West Antarctica. It marks the site of a former subduction zone on the edge of Gondwana.
The Eastern Province underlies more of New Zealand than the Western Province, including the greywacke and schist of the Southern Alps and all of the basement rocks of the North Island. The Eastern Province contains seven main terranes, the [[Drumduan Terrane|Drumduan]], [[Brook Street Terrane|Brook Street]], [[Murihiku Terrane|Murihiku]], [[Dun Mountain-Maitai Terrane|Dun Mountain-Maitai]], [[Caples Terrane|Caples]], [[Torlesse Composite Terrane|Torlesse Composite]] (Rakaia, Aspiring and Pahau terranes) and [[Waipapa Terrane|Waipapa]] Composite (Morrinsville and Hunua Terranes).<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Mortimer |first1=N. |last2=Rattenbury |first2=M. S. |last3=King |first3=P. R.|last4=Bland |first4=K. J.|last5=Barrell |first5= D. J. A.|last6=Bache |first6=F.|last7=Begg |first7= J. G.|title=High-level stratigraphic scheme for New Zealand rocks. |url= |journal=New Zealand Journal of Geology and Geophysics |volume=57 |issue=4 |pages=402-419 |doi= |access-date= }}</ref> They are mostly composed of greywacke together with [[argillite]], except for the Brook Street and Dun Mountain-Maitai Terranes which have significant igneous components (see [[Dun Mountain Ophiolite Belt]]). New Zealand's greywacke is mostly from the Caples, Torlesse Composite (Rakaia and Pahau) and Waipapa Composite (Morrinsville and Hunua) terranes formed in Carboniferous-Cretaceous time (330–120 Ma). Much of these rocks were deposited as [[submarine fan]]s. They have different origins, as shown by different chemical compositions and different [[fossils]]. In general, the sedimentary basement terranes become younger from West to East across the country, as the newer terranes were scraped off the subducting paleo-[[Pacific Plate]], and [[Accretion (geology)|accreted]] to the boundary of Gondwana over hundreds of millions of years.
Many rocks in the Eastern Province have been metamorphosed into the [[Haast Schist]], due to exposure to high pressures and temperatures. Rocks grade continuously from greywacke (e.g., in Canterbury) to high-grade schist (e.g., around the Caples-Torlesse boundary in [[Otago]] and [[Marlborough Region|Marlborough]], and [[Torlesse Composite Terrane|Torlesse]] rocks just to the East of the Alpine Fault). The Alpine Fault that corresponds to the line of the [[Southern Alps]] has separated the basement rocks that used to be adjacent by about 480 km.
==Separation from Gondwana (Cretaceous-Eocene)==
The Australia-New Zealand continental fragment of Gondwana split from the rest of Gondwana in the late Cretaceous time (95–90 Ma). Then around 83 Ma, Zealandia started to separate from Australia forming the [[Tasman Sea]], initially separating from the south. By 75 Ma, Zealandia was essentially separate from Australia and Antarctica, although only shallow seas might have separated Zealandia and Australia in the north. [[Dinosaur]]s continued to live in New Zealand after it separated from Gondwana, as shown by [[sauropod]] footprints from 70 million years ago in Nelson.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.stuff.co.nz/science/83962010/dinosaur-footprints-found-in-nelson-on-show-in-lower-hutt |title=Dinosaur footprints found in Nelson on show in Lower Hutt |last= |first= |date= |website=www.stuff.co.nz |publisher= |access-date= |quote=}}</ref> During the Cretaceous extension large [[Fault (geology)|normal faults]] formed throughout New Zealand. this meant that dinosaurs had about 20 million years to evolve unique New Zealand species. The Hawks Crag Breccia formed next to their [[Fault scarp|scarps]] and it has become New Zealand's best [[uranium]] [[mineral deposit]].<ref name="BeckReed1958">{{cite journal|last1=Beck|first1=A. C.|last2=Reed|first2=J. J.|last3=Willett|first3=R. W.|title=Uranium mineralization in the Hawks Crag Breccia of the Lower Buller Gorge Region, South Island, New Zealand|journal=New Zealand Journal of Geology and Geophysics|volume=1|issue=3|year=1958|pages=432–450|issn=0028-8306|doi=10.1080/00288306.1958.10422773}}</ref>
Currently, New Zealand has no native snakes or land mammals (other than bats). Both [[marsupials]] and [[placental]] mammals did not evolve and reach Australia in time to be on New Zealand when it drifted away 85 million years ago. The evolution and dispersal of snakes is less certain, but there is no hard evidence of them being in Australia before the opening of the Tasman Sea.<ref name="ScanlonLee2003">{{cite journal|last1=Scanlon|first1=John D.|last2=Lee|first2=Michael S.Y.|last3=Archer|first3=Michael|title=Mid-Tertiary elapid snakes (Squamata, Colubroidea) from Riversleigh, northern Australia: early steps in a continent-wide adaptive radiation|journal=Geobios|volume=36|issue=5|year=2003|pages=573–601|issn=00166995|doi=10.1016/S0016-6995(03)00056-1}}</ref> The [[multituberculates]], another type of mammal which is now extinct, may have been in time to cross the land bridge to New Zealand.<ref name="YuanJi2013">{{cite journal|last1=Yuan|first1=C.-X.|last2=Ji|first2=Q.|last3=Meng|first3=Q.-J.|last4=Tabrum|first4=A. R.|last5=Luo|first5=Z.-X.|title=Earliest Evolution of Multituberculate Mammals Revealed by a New Jurassic Fossil|journal=Science|volume=341|issue=6147|year=2013|pages=779–783|issn=0036-8075|doi=10.1126/science.1237970}}</ref>
The landmasses continued to separate until early [[Eocene]] times (53 Ma). The Tasman Sea, and part of Zealandia then locked together with Australia to form the [[Australian Plate]] (40 Ma), and a new plate boundary was created between the Australian Plate and [[Pacific Plate]]. Zealandia ended up at a pivot point between the Pacific and Australian Plates, with spreading in the south, and convergence in the north, where the Pacific Plate was subducted beneath the Australian Plate. A precursor to the [[Kermadec Arc]] was created. The convergent part of the plate boundary propagated through Zealandia from the north, eventually forming a proto-Alpine Fault in [[Miocene]] times (23 Ma). The various ridges and basins north of New Zealand relate to previous positions of the [[plate boundary]].<ref>[http://www.teara.govt.nz/EarthSeaAndSky/Geology/GeologyOverview/6/ENZ-Resources/Standard/1/en#breadcrumbtop New Zealand splits from Gondwana] from Te Ara: The Encyclopedia of New Zealand</ref>
==Sedimentary basins and allochthons (Cretaceous-Recent)== {{See also|Stratigraphy of New Zealand}} [[File:Cape Farewell Arch.jpg|thumb|left|Sedimentary rocks from an uplifted basin. Cape Farewell, South Island]] [[Erosion]] and [[deposition (geology)|deposition]] has lead to much of Zealandia now being covered in sedimentary rocks that formed in swamps and [[oceanic basin|marine sedimentary basins]]. Much of New Zealand was low lying around Mid [[Eocene]]-[[Oligocene]] times (40–23 Ma). Swamps became widespread, forming [[coal]]. The land subsided further, and marine organisms produced [[limestone]] deposits. Limestone of Oligocene-Early [[Miocene]] age formed in many areas, including the [[King Country]], known for the [[Waitomo Glowworm Cave]]. In the South Island, limestone is present in Buller, Nelson, and the [[West Coast (New Zealand)|West Coast]], including the [[Pancake Rocks]] at [[Punakaiki]] in Oligocene-Early Miocene times (34–15 Ma). It is debated whether all of New Zealand was submerged at this time or if small islands remained as "arcs" preserving fauna and flora.<ref name="KnappMudaliar2007">{{cite journal|last1=Knapp|first1=Michael|last2=Mudaliar|first2=Ragini|last3=Havell|first3=David|last4=Wagstaff|first4=Steven J.|last5=Lockhart|first5=Peter J.|last6=Paterson|first6=Adrian|title=The Drowning of New Zealand and the Problem of Agathis|journal=Systematic Biology|volume=56|issue=5|year=2007|pages=862–870|issn=1076-836X|doi=10.1080/10635150701636412}}</ref>
An [[allochthon]] is land that formed elsewhere and slid on top of other land (in other words, the material of an enormous landslide). Much of the land of [[Northland Region|Northland]] and [[East Cape]] were created in this manner.<ref name="JiaoSeward2017">{{cite journal|last1=Jiao|first1=Ruohong|last2=Seward|first2=Diane|last3=Little|first3=Timothy A.|last4=Herman|first4=Frédéric|last5=Kohn|first5=Barry P.|title=Constraining provenance, thickness and erosion of nappes using low-temperature thermochronology: the Northland Allochthon, New Zealand|journal=Basin Research|volume=29|issue=1|year=2017|pages=81–95|issn=0950091X|doi=10.1111/bre.12166}}</ref> Around 25–22 Ma, Northland and East Cape were adjacent, with East Cape near [[Whangarei]]. Northland-East Cape was an undersea basin. Much of the land that now forms Northland-East Cape was higher land to the Northeast (composed of rocks formed 90–25 Ma). The Pacific-Australian plate boundary was further to the Northeast, with the Pacific Plate subducting under the Australian Plate. Layers of rocks were peeled off the higher land, from the top down, and slid Southwest under the influence of gravity, to be stacked the right way up, but in reverse order. Most of the material to slide were sedimentary rocks, however, the last rocks to be slid across were slabs of [[oceanic crust]] ([[ophiolite]]s), mainly [[basalt]]. Widespread volcanic activity also occurred (23–15 Ma), and is intermixed with the foreign rocks. Sedimentary basins formed on the allochthons while they were moving. East Cape was later separated from Northland and moved further south and east to its present position.
==Volcanic activity== {{Main article|Volcanism of New Zealand}}
Volcanism is recorded in New Zealand throughout its whole geological history. Most volcanism in New Zealand, both modern and ancient, has been caused by the subduction of one tectonic plate under another, this causes melting in the [[mantle (geology)|mantle]], the layer of the earth below the crust. This produces a [[volcanic arc]], composed of mainly [[basalt]], [[andesitic]] and [[rhyolitic]]. Basaltic eruptions tend to be fairly placid, producing scoria cones and lava flows, such as the volcanic cones in the [[Auckland volcanic field]], although [[Mount Tarawera]]'s violent 1886 eruption was an exception. Andesitic eruptions tend to form steep [[stratovolcanoes]], including mountains such as [[Mount Ruapehu|Ruapehu]], [[Tongariro]] and [[Taranaki]], islands such as [[Little Barrier Island|Little Barrier]], [[Whakaari / White Island|White]] and [[Raoul Island]]s, or submarine [[seamount]]s like [[Monowai Seamount]]. Rhyolitic eruptions with large amounts of water tend to cause violent eruptions, producing [[calderas]], such as [[Lake Taupo]] and [[Lake Rotorua]]. New Zealand also has many volcanoes which are not clearly related to plate subduction including the extinct [[Dunedin Volcano]] and [[Banks Peninsula]], and the dormant [[Auckland Volcanic Field]].
===Extinct volcanoes===
The South Island has no currently active volcanoes. However, in the late [[Cretaceous]] (100–65 Ma), there was widespread volcanic activity in Marlborough, West Coast, Canterbury and Otago; and in [[Eocene]] times (40 Ma), there was volcanic activity in [[Oamaru]]. The most well known [[Miocene]] volcanic centres are the intra-plate [[Dunedin Volcano]] and [[Banks Peninsula]]s. The Dunedin Volcano which later eroded to form [[Otago Peninsula]] near [[Dunedin]] was built up by a series of mainly basaltic intra-plate volcanic eruptions in Miocene times (16–10 Ma).<ref>[http://www.otago.ac.nz/geology/people/students/martin_u/index.html ''"Eruptions and deposition of volcaniclastic rocks in the Dunedin Volcanic Complex, Otago Peninsula, New Zealand"'', Ulrike Martin]</ref> Banks Peninsula near [[Christchurch]] was built from two mainly basaltic intra-plate volcanoes in Miocene times (12–6 Ma and 9.5–7.5 Ma), corresponding to the [[Lyttelton Harbour|Lyttelton]] and [[Akaroa]] Harbours. Southland's [[Solander Islands]] were active around 1 to 2 million years ago. There are also minor volcanic from a similar time period throughout Canterbury, Otago and also on the [[Chatham Islands]].
[[File:Pillow lava Oamaru New Zealand.jpg|thumb|Ancient underwater volcanic eruptions ([[pillow lava]]) near [[Oamaru]].]]
Intra-plate basaltic volcanic eruptions also occurred in the North Island, near the [[Bay of Islands]] in Northland, in the Late Miocene (10 Mya), and again more recently (0.5 Mya). The [[South Auckland volcanic field]] was active in [[Pleistocene]] times (1.5–0.5 Ma). The [[Auckland volcanic field]] started erupting around 250,000 years ago. It includes around 50 distinct eruptions, with most of the prominent cones formed in the last 30,000 years, and the most recent eruption, which formed [[Rangitoto Island]], around 600 years ago. The field is currently dormant and further eruptions are expected. Over time the volcanic field has slowly been drifting northwards.<ref name="MolloyShane2009">{{cite journal|last1=Molloy|first1=Catherine|last2=Shane|first2=Phil|last3=Augustinus|first3=Paul|title=Eruption recurrence rates in a basaltic volcanic field based on tephra layers in maar sediments: Implications for hazards in the Auckland volcanic field|journal=Geological Society of America Bulletin|volume=121|issue=11-12|year=2009|pages=1666–1677|issn=0016-7606|doi=10.1130/B26447.1}}</ref>
Volcanism in the North Island has been dominated by a series of volcanic arcs which have evolved into the still active [[Taupo Volcanic Zone]]. Over time, volcanic activity has moved south and east, as the plate boundary moved eastward. This started in Miocene times (23 Ma) when a volcanic arc became active to the west of Northland, and gradually moved South down to [[New Plymouth]], where [[Mount Taranaki/Egmont|Taranaki]] is still active. It produced mainly andesitic strato-volcanoes. The Northland volcanoes include the volcanoes that produced the [[Waipoua Plateau]] (site of [[Waipoua Forest]], with large [[Kauri]] trees) and [[Kaipara District|Kaipara]] volcano. The Waitakere volcano (22–16 Ma) has mainly been eroded, but [[Conglomerate (geology)|conglomerate]] from the volcano forms the [[Waitakere Ranges]], and produced most of the material that makes up the [[Waitemata sandstones]] and mudstones.<ref name="Hayward1979">{{cite journal|last1=Hayward|first1=Bruce W.|title=Eruptive history of the early to mid miocene Waitakere volcanic arc, and palaeogeography of the Waitemata Basin, Northern New Zealand|journal=Journal of the Royal Society of New Zealand|volume=9|issue=3|year=1979|pages=297–320|issn=0303-6758|doi=10.1080/03036758.1979.10419410}}</ref> [[Lahars]] produced the coarser Parnell Grit. Notable visible volcanoes in the Waikato include [[Karioi]] and [[Pirongia]] (2.5 Ma). The volcanoes off the West coast of the North Island, together with Taranaki and the Tongariro Volcanic Centre, are responsible for the black iron sand on many of the beaches between Taranaki and [[Auckland]].
Shortly after (18 Ma), a volcanic arc developed further east to create the [[Coromandel Range]]s and undersea [[Colville Ridge]]. The initial activity was andesitic but later became rhyolitic (12 Ma). In the [[Kauaeranga Valley]], [[volcanic plugs]] remain, as does a lava lake that now forms the top of [[Table Mountain (New Zealand)|Table Mountain]]. Active [[geothermal systems]], similar to those that now exist near [[Rotorua]], were present around 6 Ma, and produced the [[gold]] and [[silver]] deposits that were later [[Mining|mine]]d in the [[Coromandel gold rush]]. Later (5–2 Ma), volcanic activity moved further south to form the [[Kaimai Range]].
===Active volcanoes and geothermal areas===
After this, activity shifted further East to the Taupo Volcanic Zone, which runs from the [[Tongariro Volcanic Centre]] ([[Mount Ruapehu|Ruapehu]] and [[Tongariro]]), through [[Taupo]], [[Rotorua]], and out to sea to form the Kermadec Ridge. Activity was initiated around 2 Ma, and continues to this day. The Tongariro Volcanic Centre is composed of andesitic volcanoes, while the areas around Taupo and Rotorua are largely rhyolitic with minor basalt. Early eruptions between Taupo and Rotorua around 1.25 Ma, and 1 Ma, were large enough to produce an [[ignimbrite]] sheet that reached [[Auckland]], [[Napier, New Zealand|Napier]], and [[Gisborne, New Zealand|Gisborne]]. This includes vast [[pumice]] deposits generated from eruptions in the Taupo Volcanic Zone occur throughout the central North Island, Bay of Plenty, [[Waikato]], [[King Country]] and [[Wanganui]] regions. Every so often, there are swarms of [[earthquakes]] within an area of the Taupo Volcanic Zone, which last for years. These earthquake swarms indicate that some movement of [[magma]] is occurring below the surface. While they have not resulted in an eruption in recent times, there is always the potential for a new volcano to be created, or a dormant volcano to come to life.
[[File:1 White Island.jpg|thumb|left|Eruption of [[Whakaari / White Island|White Island]], New Zealand's most active volcano,[[Bay of Plenty]].]]
The Tongariro Volcanic Centre developed over the last 275,000 years and contains the active andesitic volcanic cones of Ruapehu, Tongariro, and [[Ngauruhoe]] (really a side cone of Tongariro). Ruapehu erupts about once a decade, and while the eruptions cause havoc for skiers, plane flights and hydroelectric dams, the eruptions are relatively minor. However, the sudden collapse of the crater wall caused major problems when it generated a [[lahar]] in 1953, that destroyed a rail bridge, and caused 151 deaths at [[Tangiwai]]. The last significant eruption was 1995–96. Ngauruhoe last erupted 1973–75. Taranaki is a perfectly formed andesitic strato-volcano, that last erupted in 1755.
[[Lake Taupo]], the largest lake in the North Island, is a [[volcanic caldera]], responsible for rhyolitic eruptions about once every 1,000 years.<ref>{{cite web |title=Taupo – Eruptive History |url=http://www.volcano.si.edu/world/volcano.cfm?vnum=0401-07=&volpage=erupt | work = Global Volcanism Program | publisher = [[Smithsonian Institution]] |accessdate=2008-03-16}}</ref> The largest eruption in the last 65,000 years was the cataclysmic [[Oruanui Eruption]] 26,500 years ago, producing 530 cubic kilometres of magma. The most recent eruption, around 233 AD was also a major event, the biggest eruption worldwide in the last 5,000 years. The eruption caused a pyroclastic flow that devastated the land from [[Waiouru]] to [[Rotorua]] in 10 minutes.
The [[Okataina]] volcanic centre, to the East of Rotorua, is also responsible for major cataclysmic rhyolitic eruptions. The last eruption, of [[Mount Tarawera|Tarawera]] and [[Lake Rotomahana]] in 1886, was a relatively minor eruption, which was thought to have destroyed the famous [[Pink and White Terraces]], and covered much of the surrounding countryside in ash, killing over 100 people. In 2017 researchers rediscovered the locations of the Pink and White Terraces using a forgotten survey from 1859.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Bunn|first=Rex|last2=Nolden|first2=Sascha|date=2017-06-07|title=Forensic cartography with Hochstetter’s 1859 Pink and White Terraces survey: Te Otukapuarangi and Te Tarata|url=https://dx.doi.org/10.1080/03036758.2017.1329748|journal=Journal of the Royal Society of New Zealand|volume=0|issue=0|pages=1–18|doi=10.1080/03036758.2017.1329748|issn=0303-6758}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Bunn and Nolden|first=Rex and Sascha|date=December 2016|title=Te Tarata and Te Otukapuarangi: Reverse engineering Hochstetter’s Lake Rotomahana Survey to map the Pink and White Terrace locations|url=https://ojs.victoria.ac.nz/jnzs/article/view/3988/3555|journal=Journal of New Zealand Studies|volume=NS23|pages=37–53|via=}}</ref> Many lakes around Rotorua are [[calderas]] from rhyolitic eruptions. For example, [[Lake Rotorua]] erupted around 13,500 years ago.
A line of undersea volcanoes extends out along the [[Kermadec Ridge]]. [[Whakaari/White Island|White Island]], in the Bay of Plenty, represents the southern end of this chain and is a very active andesitic volcano, erupting with great frequency. It has the potential to cause a tsunami in the Bay of Plenty, as does the dormant [[Mayor Island]] volcano.
The Taupo Volcanic Zone is known for its [[geothermal]] activity. For example, Rotorua and the surrounding area have many areas with [[geysers]], [[silica terrace]]s, [[fumaroles]], [[mudpot|mud-pool]]s, [[hot springs]], etc. Notable geothermal areas include [[Whakarewarewa]], [[Tikitere]], [[Waimangu Volcanic Rift Valley|Waimangu]], [[Waiotapu]], [[Craters of the Moon (geothermal site)|Craters of the Moon]] and [[Orakei Korako]]. Geothermal energy is used to generate electricity at [[Wairakei]], near [[Taupo]]. Hot pools abound throughout New Zealand. [[Geothermal energy]] is used to generate electricity in the Taupo Volcanic Zone.<ref>Matthew Hall (2004) [http://www.med.govt.nz/upload/24445/geothermal.pdf Existing and Potential Geothermal Resource for Electricity Generation]. Ministry for Economic Development.</ref>
==Modern tectonic setting and earthquakes==
{{Main article|List of earthquakes in New Zealand}}
[[File:NZ faults.png|thumb|250px|Major [[active fault]] zones of New Zealand showing variation in displacement vector of [[Pacific Plate]] relative to [[Indo-Australian Plate|Australian Plate]] along the boundary]] New Zealand is currently astride the convergent boundary between the Pacific and Australian Plates. Over time, the relative motion of the plates has altered and the current configuration is geologically recent. Currently the Pacific Plate is subducted beneath the Australian Plate from around [[Tonga]] in the north, through the [[Tonga Trench]], [[Kermadec Trench]], and [[Hikurangi Trough]] to the east of the [[North Island]] of New Zealand, down to [[Cook Strait]]. Through most of the [[South Island]], the plates slide past each other ([[Alpine Fault]]), with slight [[obduction]] of the Pacific Plate over the Australian Plate, forming [[Southern Alps]]. From [[Fiordland]] south, the Australian Plate subducts under the Pacific Plate forming the [[Puysegur Trench]].<ref>[http://www.teara.govt.nz/EarthSeaAndSky/Geology/GeologyOverview/1/ENZ-Resources/Standard/2/en#breadcrumbtop Diagram showing the Australian-Pacific Plate Boundary]</ref> This configuration has lead to volcanism and extension in the North Island forming the Taupo Volcanic Zone and uplift in the South Island forming the Southern Alps.
The Pacific Plate is colliding with the Australian Plate at a rate of about 40 mm/yr.<ref name="DeMetsGordon1990">{{cite journal|last1=DeMets|first1=C.|last2=Gordon|first2=R. G.|last3=Argus|first3=D. F.|last4=Stein|first4=S.|year=1990|title=Current plate motions|journal=Geophysical Journal International|volume=101|issue=2|pages=425–478|doi=10.1111/j.1365-246X.1990.tb06579.x|issn=0956540X}}</ref> The East coast of the North Island is being compressed and lifted by this collision, producing the [[North Island Fault System|North Island]] and [[Marlborough Fault System]]s. The East Coast of the North Island is also rotating clockwise, relative to Northland, [[Auckland]] and [[Taranaki]], stretching the [[Bay of Plenty]], and producing the [[Hauraki Rift]] (Hauraki Plains and Hauraki Gulf) and Taupo Volcanic Zone. The East Coast of the South Island is sliding obliquely towards the Alpine Fault, relative to [[Westland District|Westland]], causing the Southern Alps to rise about 10 mm/yr (although they are also worn down at a similar rate).<ref name="LittleCox2005">{{cite journal|last1=Little|first1=Timothy A.|last2=Cox|first2=Simon|last3=Vry|first3=Julie K.|last4=Batt|first4=Geoffrey|year=2005|title=Variations in exhumation level and uplift rate along the obliqu-slip Alpine fault, central Southern Alps, New Zealand|journal=Geological Society of America Bulletin|volume=117|issue=5|pages=707|doi=10.1130/B25500.1|issn=0016-7606}}</ref> The [[Hauraki Plains]], [[Hamilton, New Zealand|Hamilton]], Bay of Plenty, [[Marlborough Sounds]], and [[Christchurch]] are sinking. The Marlborough Sounds are known for their sunken mountain ranges. As [[Wellington]] rises, and Marlborough sinks, [[Cook Strait]] is being shifted further south. <ref>[http://www.teara.govt.nz/EarthSeaAndSky/Geology/GeologyOverview/11/ENZ-Resources/Standard/3/en#breadcrumbtop New Zealand uplift and sinking] from Te Ara: The Encyclopedia of New Zealand</ref>
Great [[Stress (mechanics)|stress]] is built up in the earth's crust due to the constant movement of the tectonic plates. This stress is released by [[earthquake|earthquakes]], which can occur on the plate boundary or on any of thousands of smaller faults throughout New Zealand. Because the Pacific Plate is subducting under the eastern side of the North Island, there are frequent deep earthquakes east of a line from the Bay of Plenty to Nelson (the approximate edge of the subducted plate), with the earthquakes being deeper to the west, and shallower to the east. Because the Australian Plate is subducting under the Pacific Plate in [[Fiordland]], there are frequent deep earthquakes near Fiordland, with the earthquakes being deeper to the east and shallower near the west.
Shallow earthquakes are more widespread, occurring almost everywhere throughout New Zealand (especially the Bay of Plenty, [[East Cape]] to Marlborough, and Alpine Fault). However, Northland, [[Waikato]], and [[Otago]] are relatively stable. [[Canterbury, New Zealand|Canterbury]] had been without a major earthquake in recorded history until the {{M|w}} 7.1 [[2010 Canterbury earthquake|Canterbury earthquake]] on 4 September 2010. The volcanic activity in the central North island also creates many shallow earthquakes.
==Paleoclimate of New Zealand== {{See also|Climate change in New Zealand|}} [[File:All palaeotemps.svg|thumb|right|600px|Global palaeotemperature graphs (compressed scale) note the warmer Eocene and Miocene in green and the [[Ice Age]] in blue.]] Since Zealandia separated from Gondwana (80 mya) in the Cretaceous the climate has typically been far warmer than today. However, since the [[Quaternary glaciation]] (2.9 mya) Zealandia has experienced climate either cooler or only slightly warmer than today.
In the Cretaceous, New Zealand was positioned at 80 degrees south at the boundary between Antarctica and Australia. But it was covered in trees as the climate of 90 million years ago was much warmer and wetter than today.<ref name="McGloneBuitenwerf2016">{{cite journal|last1=McGlone|first1=MS|last2=Buitenwerf|first2=R|last3=Richardson|first3=SJ|title=The formation of the oceanic temperate forests of New Zealand|journal=New Zealand Journal of Botany|volume=54|issue=2|year=2016|pages=128–155|issn=0028-825X|doi=10.1080/0028825X.2016.1158196}}</ref> During the warm Eocene Period vast swamps covered New Zealand which became coal seams in Southland and [[Waikato]]. In the Miocene there are [[palaeontology|paleontological]] records of [[Saint Bathans Fauna|warm lakes in Central Otago]] with palm trees and [[Saint Bathans mammal|small land mammal]]s.<ref name="WorthyTennyson2006">{{cite journal|last1=Worthy|first1=T. H.|last2=Tennyson|first2=A. J. D.|last3=Archer|first3=M.|last4=Musser|first4=A. M.|last5=Hand|first5=S. J.|last6=Jones|first6=C.|last7=Douglas|first7=B. J.|last8=McNamara|first8=J. A.|last9=Beck|first9=R. M. D.|title=Miocene mammal reveals a Mesozoic ghost lineage on insular New Zealand, southwest Pacific|journal=Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences|volume=103|issue=51|year=2006|pages=19419–19423|issn=0027-8424|doi=10.1073/pnas.0605684103}}</ref>
Over the past 30,000 years three major climate events are recorded in New Zealand, the [[last glacial maximum|last glacial maximum's]] coldest period from 28-18,000 years ago, a transitional period from 18-11,000 years ago and the Holocene Inter Glacial which has been occurring for the past 11,000 years.<ref name="AllowayLowe2007">{{cite journal|last1=Alloway|first1=Brent V.|last2=Lowe|first2=David J.|last3=Barrell|first3=David J. A.|last4=Newnham|first4=Rewi M.|last5=Almond|first5=Peter C.|last6=Augustinus|first6=Paul C.|last7=Bertler|first7=Nancy A. N.|last8=Carter|first8=Lionel|last9=Litchfield|first9=Nicola J.|last10=McGlone|first10=Matt S.|last11=Shulmeister|first11=Jamie|last12=Vandergoes|first12=Marcus J.|last13=Williams|first13=Paul W.|title=Towards a climate event stratigraphy for New Zealand over the past 30 000 years (NZ-INTIMATE project)|journal=Journal of Quaternary Science|volume=22|issue=1|year=2007|pages=9–35|issn=02678179|doi=10.1002/jqs.1079}}</ref> Throughout the last glacial maximum, global sea levels were about {{convert|130|m|abbr=off}} lower than present levels. When this happened the North Island, South Island, and [[Stewart Island]] were joined together.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.gns.cri.nz/static/nzpaleoclimate/images/NZpaleoclimate_poster.jpg |title=NZ paleoclimate poster |last= |first= |date= |website=www.gns.cri.nz |publisher=GNS Science |access-date= |quote=}}</ref> Temperatures dropped by about 4–5 °C. Much of the [[Southern Alps]] and [[Fiordland]] were glaciated, but the rest of New Zealand was largely ice-free. The land to the North of [[Hamilton, New Zealand|Hamilton]] was forested, but much of the rest of New Zealand was covered in grass or shrubs, due to the cold and dry climate.<ref name="WilliamsMcGlone2015">{{cite journal|last1=Williams|first1=Paul W.|last2=McGlone|first2=Matt|last3=Neil|first3=Helen|last4=Zhao|first4=Jian-Xin|title=A review of New Zealand palaeoclimate from the Last Interglacial to the global Last Glacial Maximum|journal=Quaternary Science Reviews|volume=110|year=2015|pages=92–106|issn=02773791|doi=10.1016/j.quascirev.2014.12.017}}</ref><ref>[http://www.teara.govt.nz/EarthSeaAndSky/Geology/GeologyOverview/8/ENZ-Resources/Standard/4/en#breadcrumbtop New Zealand during the last glacial maximum] from Te Ara: The Encyclopedia of New Zealand</ref> This lack of vegetation cover lead to greater wind erosion and the deposition of [[loess]] (windblown dust).<ref name="AllowayLowe2007">{{cite journal|last1=Alloway|first1=Brent V.|last2=Lowe|first2=David J.|last3=Barrell|first3=David J. A.|last4=Newnham|first4=Rewi M.|last5=Almond|first5=Peter C.|last6=Augustinus|first6=Paul C.|last7=Bertler|first7=Nancy A. N.|last8=Carter|first8=Lionel|last9=Litchfield|first9=Nicola J.|last10=McGlone|first10=Matt S.|last11=Shulmeister|first11=Jamie|last12=Vandergoes|first12=Marcus J.|last13=Williams|first13=Paul W.|title=Towards a climate event stratigraphy for New Zealand over the past 30 000 years (NZ-INTIMATE project)|journal=Journal of Quaternary Science|volume=22|issue=1|year=2007|pages=9–35|issn=02678179|doi=10.1002/jqs.1079}}</ref> The study of New Zealand's paleoclimate has settled some of the debate regarding links between the [[Little Ice Age]] (LIA) in the Northern Hemisphere and the climate in New Zealand at the same time. The key facts to emerge are that New Zealand did experience a noticeable cooler climate, but at a slightly later date than in the [[Northern Hemisphere]]. <ref name="NIWA">{{cite web|url=https://www.niwa.co.nz/our-science/climate/information-and-resources/clivar/pastclimate|title=Past climate variations over New Zealand|author=David Wratt|author2=Jim Salinger|author3=Rob Bell|author4=Drew Lorrey|author5=Brett Mullan|last-author-amp=yes|publisher=NIWA|accessdate=5 June 2014}}</ref>
==Geological hazards== [[File:Christchurch Earthquake 220211.jpg|thumb|right|Earthquake damage in Christchurch (2011).]]
New Zealand suffers from many natural hazards, including [[earthquakes]] and [[tsunamis]], volcanic and hydrothermal eruptions and [[landslides]].
The largest earthquake in New Zealand was an M8.2 event in the [[Wairarapa]], in 1855,<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.gns.cri.nz/Home/Learning/Science-Topics/Earthquakes/New-Zealand-Earthquakes/Where-were-NZs-largest-earthquakes|title=Where were NZs largest earthquakes? / New Zealand Earthquakes / Earthquakes / Science Topics / Learning / Home - GNS Science|last=Science|first=GNS|website=www.gns.cri.nz|language=en-GB|access-date=2018-11-27}}</ref> and the most deaths (261) occurred in a M7.8 earthquake in [[Hawkes Bay]] in 1931. Widespread property damage was caused by the [[2010 Canterbury earthquake]], which measured 7.1; The M6.3 aftershock of 22 February 2011 ([[2011 Canterbury earthquake]]) resulted in 185 fatalities. Most recently, the M7.8 [[2016 Kaikoura earthquake|Kaikoura earthquake]] struck just after midnight on November 14, 2016, killing two people in the remote Kaikoura area northeast of Christchurch Numerous aftershocks of M5.0 or greater are spread over a large area between Wellington and Culverden.
New Zealand is at risk from tsunamis that are generated from both local and international faults. The eastern coast of New Zealand is most at risk as the [[Pacific Ocean]] is more tectonically active than the [[Tasman Sea]]. Locally the faults along the North Islands east coast provide the greatest risk. Minor tsunamis have occurred in New Zealand from earthquakes in Chile, Alaska and Japan.
There are many potentially dangerous volcanoes in the Taupo Volcanic Zone. The most severe volcanic eruption since the arrival of Europeans is the [[Mount Tarawera|Tarawera]] eruption in 1886. A [[lahar]] from Mount Ruapehu [[Tangiwai disaster|derailed a train]] in 1955 killing 151 people. Even a minor eruption at Ruapehu could cause the loss of electricity for Auckland, due to ash on the power lines, and in the [[Waikato River]] (stopping the generation of hydroelectric power).
Many parts of New Zealand are susceptible to landslides, particaly due to deforestaion and the high earthquake risk. Much of the North Island is steep, and composed of soft mudstone known as papa,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.teara.govt.nz/en/rock-and-mineral-names/1 |title=Rock and mineral names – Local names |first=Simon |last=Nathan |date=2 March 2009 |work=Te Ara – the Encyclopedia of New Zealand |accessdate=28 December 2011}}</ref> that easily generates landslides.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.teara.govt.nz/en/rock-and-mineral-names/1/5 |title=Rock and mineral names |first=Simon |last=Nathan |date=24 September 2011 |work=Te Ara – the Encyclopedia of New Zealand |accessdate=28 December 2011}}</ref>
==Geological resources==
{{Main article|Mining in New Zealand|Oil and gas industry in New Zealand}}
New Zealand main geological resources are Coal, Gold, Oil and natural gas.<ref name="CM-c">{{cite web|url=http://www.crownminerals.govt.nz/cms/coal/overview|title=Coal Overview|publisher=Crown Minerals, Ministry of Economic Development|date=17 December 2008}}</ref><ref>"[http://gogold.co.nz/nz-gold-history/ NZ Gold History] {{webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20140205023810/http://gogold.co.nz/nz-gold-history/ |date=5 February 2014 }}," New Zealand Gold Merchants Ltd., retrieved 5 February 2014.</ref> [[Coal]] has been mined in Northland, the [[Waikato]], Taranaki, Nelson and Westland, Canterbury, Otago, and Southland. The [[West Coast (New Zealand)|West Coast]] contains some of New Zealand’s best [[bituminous coal]]. The largest coal deposits occur in Southland.[[Gold]] has been mined in the [[Coromandel Range|Coromandel]] and [[Kaimai Range]]s (especially the [[Martha Mine]] at [[Waihi]]), [[Westland District|Westland]], [[Central Otago]], and Eastern Otago (especially [[Macraes Mine]]), and on the west coast of the South Island. The only area in New Zealand with significant known oil and gas deposits is the [[Taranaki]] area, but many other offshore areas have the potential for deposits.<ref name="CM-p">{{cite web |url=http://www.crownminerals.govt.nz/cms/petroleum/overview |title=Petroleum Overview |publisher=Crown Minerals, Ministry of Economic Development |date=26 June 2008}}</ref> [[Iron sand]] is also plentiful on the west coast from Taranaki to [[Auckland]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://quarryingandminingmag.co.nz/q-m/mining/ironsands/|title=Huge ironsands expansion - Quarrying & Mining Magazine|date=2014-11-11|work=Quarrying & Mining Magazine|access-date=2018-02-01|language=en-US}}</ref> [[Jade]] ([[Pounamu]] in [[Māori language|Māori]]) from South Island [[ophiolite|ophiolites]] continues to be extracted, mostly from [[alluvium]], and worked for sale. [[Groundwater]] reservoirs are extracted throughout the country, but are particularly valuable in the dryer eastern regions of both the North and South Islands.
==The history of New Zealand geology== [[Image:AucklandMapHochstetter1859.JPG|thumb|right|200px|Hochstetter's map of the [[Auckland volcanic field]] (1859).]] The detailed study of New Zealand's geology began with [[Julius von Haast]] and [[Ferdinand von Hochstetter]] who created numerous regional [[geological map]]s of the country during resource exploration in the mid-late 1800's.<ref>[http://sp.lyellcollection.org/content/287/1/375.abstract Johnston, M. R.; ''Nineteenth-century observations of the Dun Mountain Ophiolite Belt, Nelson, New Zealand and trans-Tasman correlations,'' Geological Society, London, Special Publications 2007, v. 287, p. 375-387]</ref> In 1865 [[James Hector]] was appointed to found the [[Geological Survey of New Zealand]]. [[Patrick Marshall]] coined the terms ''[[andesite line]]'' and ''[[ignimbrite]]'' in the early 1900's while working in the Taupo Volcanic Zone. [[Harold Wellman]] discovered the Alpine Fault and its 480 km offset in 1941. Even though Wellman proved that large block of land could move consid erable distances the New Zealand geological survey was largely a late adopter of plate tectonics.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.co.nz/books?id=5oJPAQAAIAAJ&q=new+zealand+geology&dq=new+zealand+geology&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiM8NDT-e3eAhVQFHIKHV66BsYQ6AEIPzAE|title=The Geology of New Zealand|last=Suggate|first=Richard Patrick|last2=Punga|first2=Martin Theodore Te|date=1978|publisher=E.C. Keating, Government Printer|isbn=9780477010573|language=en}}</ref>
[[Charles Cotton (geologist)|Charles Cotton]] became an international authority on [[geomorphology]] using New Zealand active tectonics and variable climate to create universally applicably rules<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.co.nz/books?id=jVIjECjQMfEC&pg=PA295&dq=geomorphology+zealand+cotton&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiWp--m-O3eAhXKWisKHa_bD7sQ6AEIKjAA#v=onepage&q=geomorphology%20zealand%20cotton&f=false|title=History of Geomorphology and Quaternary Geology|last=Grapes|first=R. H.|date=2008|publisher=Geological Society of London|year=|isbn=9781862392557|location=|pages=295|language=en}}</ref>. His major works becoming standard text books in New Zealand and overseas<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.co.nz/books?id=oe9pswEACAAJ&dq=geomorphology+zealand+cotton&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiWp--m-O3eAhXKWisKHa_bD7sQ6AEIPTAE|title=Geomorphology of New Zealand, Vol. 1: An Introduction to the Study of Land-Forms (Classic Reprint)|last=Cotton|first=C. A.|date=2018-02-07|publisher=Fb&c Limited|isbn=9780267981571|language=en}}</ref>. [[Charles Fleming (ornithologist)|Charles Fleming]] established the Wanganui Basin as a classic site for studying past sea levels and climates. In 1975 the [[palaeontologist]] [[Joan Wiffen]] discovered the first dinosaur fossils in New Zealand.
The Geological Survey of New Zealand now known as [[GNS Science]] has done extensive mapping through New Zealand at 1:250,000 and 1:50:000 scales. The most modern map series are the "QMAPs" at 1:250,000.<ref>[http://www.gns.cri.nz/ GNS Science]</ref> New Zealand's geological research is published by GNS Science, in the New Zealand Journal of Geology and Geophysics, and internationally. A Map showing the distribution of earthquakes in New Zealand can be obtained from Te Ara: The Encyclopedia of New Zealand.<ref>[http://www.teara.govt.nz/EarthSeaAndSky/NaturalHazardsAndDisasters/Earthquakes/1/ENZ-Resources/Standard/1/en Map showing the distribution of earthquakes in New Zealand] from Te Ara: The Encyclopedia of New Zealand.</ref> Current earthquake and volcanic activity can be obtained from the GeoNet website.<ref>[http://www.geonet.org.nz/index.html Geonet] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080108165713/http://www.geonet.org.nz/index.html|date=January 8, 2008}} – Current New Zealand Earthquake and Volcanic Activity.</ref> The universities of [[University of Auckland|Auckland]], [[University of Canterbury|Canterbury]], [[Massey University|Massey]], [[University of Otago|Otago]], [[Victoria University of Wellington|Victoria]] and [[University of Waikato|Waikato]] are activity engaged in geological research in New Zealand, [[Antarctica]], the wider South Pacific and elsewhere.

===Regional geology=== {{div col|colwidth=30em}} *[[Geology of the Northland Region]] *[[Geology of the Auckland Region]] **[[Auckland volcanic field]] *[[Geology of the Waikato-King Country Region]] *[[Taupo Volcanic Zone]] **[[Whakaari / White Island]] **[[Rotorua Caldera]] **[[Mount Tarawera]] **[[Taupo Volcano]] **[[Mount Tongariro]] **[[Mount Ngauruhoe]] **[[Mount Ruapehu]] *[[Geology of the Raukumara Region]] *[[Geology of Taranaki]] **[[Mount Taranaki/Egmont]] *[[Geology of the Wellington Region]] *[[Geology of the Tasman District]] *[[Geology of Canterbury, New Zealand]] *[[Geology of the Otago Region]] {{div col end}}
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}
==Further reading== *Graham, Ian J. et al.;''A continent on the move : New Zealand geoscience into the 21st century'' – The Geological Society of New Zealand in association with GNS Science, 2008. {{ISBN|978-1-877480-00-3}} *Campbell, Hamish; Hutching, Gerard; ''In Search of Ancient New Zealand'', Penguin Books in association with GNS Science, 2007, {{ISBN|978-0-14-302088-2}} *Te Ara: The Encyclopedia of New Zealand [http://www.teara.govt.nz/EarthSeaAndSky/Geology/GeologyOverview/en An Overview of New Zealand Geology] *''Hot Stuff to Cold Stone'' – Aitken, Jefley; GNS Science, 1997. {{ISBN|0-478-09602-X}}. *''Rocked and Ruptured'' – Aitken, Jefley; Reed Books, in association with GNS Science, 1999. {{ISBN|0-7900-0720-7}}. *''The Rise and Fall of the Southern Alps'' – Coates, Glenn; Canterbury University Press, 2002. {{ISBN|0-908812-93-0}}. *''Plate Tectonics for Curious Kiwis'' – Aitken, Jefley; GNS Science, 1996. {{ISBN|0-478-09555-4}}. *''Lava and Strata: A guide to the volcanoes and rock formations of Auckland'' – Homer, Lloyd; Moore, Phil & Kermode, Les; Landscape Publications and the Institute of Geological and Nuclear Sciences, 2000. {{ISBN|0-908800-02-9}}. *''Vanishing volcanoes : a guide to the landforms and rock formations of Coromandel Peninsula'' – Homer, Lloyd; Moore, Phil; Landscape Publications and the Institute of Geological and Nuclear Sciences, 1992. {{ISBN|0-908800-01-0}}. *''Reading the rocks : a guide to geological features of the Wairarapa Coast'' – Homer, Lloyd; Moore, Phil & Kermode, Les; Landscape Publications and the Institute of Geological and Nuclear Sciences, 1989. {{ISBN|0-908800-00-2}}

revision.comment: Fixing reference errors
revision.text:
[[File:Nationalmuseum-karta.png|thumb|300px|'''Above:''' Map showing photographer's view ({{coord|59.3275|N|18.0725|E|type:landmark|display=inline}}) of two buildings at a distance of 270 meters ({{coord|59.3284|N|18.0772|E|type:landmark|display=inline}}) and 1200 meters ({{coord|59.3291|N|18.0931|E|type:landmark|display=inline}}). '''Below:''' Which of the three locations should be associated with the resulting photo?[[File:Nationalmuseum.jpg|300px]]]] A '''geotagged photograph''' is a [[photograph]] which is associated with a geographical location by [[geotagging]]. Usually this is done by assigning at least a [[latitude]] and [[longitude]] to the image, and optionally altitude, compass bearing and other fields may also be included.
In theory, every part of a picture can be tied to a geographic location, but in the most typical application, only the position of the photographer is associated with the entire digital image. This has implications for search and retrieval. For example, photos of a mountain summit can be taken from different positions miles apart. To find all images of a particular summit in an image database, all photos taken within a reasonable distance must be considered. The point position of the photographer can in some cases include the [[Bearing (navigation)|bearing]], the direction the camera was pointing, as well as the elevation and the [[Dilution of precision (GPS)|DOP]].
==Methods of geotagging photographs== There are a few methods of geotagging photographs, either automatic or manual. Automatic methods provide the easiest and most precise method of geotagging an image, providing that a good signal has been acquired at the time of taking the photo.
===Automatic using a built-in GPS=== Several manufacturers offer cameras with a built-in GPS receiver, but most cameras with this capability are [[camera phone]]s as camera manufacturers after initial experience in the market came to treat GPS cameras as a [[niche market]].<ref>[http://gadgetwise.blogs.nytimes.com/2010/07/28/why-dont-more-cameras-offer-gps/ New York Times Gadgetwise 2010/07/28] Why don't more cameras offer GPS?</ref> The 2008 Nikon P6000, for example, an early geotagging camera, was replaced in 2010 by the P7000 which lacked that feature.<ref>[http://crave.cnet.co.uk/digitalcameras/nikon-coolpix-p7000-nikon-says-no-to-gps-50000673/ CNET UK] Nikon says No to GPS</ref> Some models also include a compass to indicate the direction the camera was facing when the picture was taken.
* [[Canon EOS 6D]] * [[Canon_PowerShot_S#Super_Zoom_S.2FSX_series|Canon PowerShot SX280HS]] * [[Canon PowerShot S100]] * [[Fujifilm FinePix F550EXR]] * [[Fujifilm FinePix F770EXR]] * [[Nikon COOLPIX P330]] * [[Nikon COOLPIX P6000]] * [[Panasonic Lumix DMC-TZ10]] * [[Sony Alpha 55]]V ([[DSLR]]) * [[Sony Alpha 65]]V ([[DSLR]]) * Some mobile phones with [[assisted GPS]] use the cell phone network to speed GPS [[Time to First Fix|acquisition time]]s.
===Automatic using a connected GPS=== [[File:Solmeta N2 auf Nikon D5000 Rueckansicht.JPG|thumb|Geotagger "Solmeta N2 Compass" + Nikon D5000]] The [[Nikon D1#D1H and D1X|D1X and D1H]] that Nikon introduced in 2002 included a GPS interface.<ref>http://www.nikonsupport.eu/europe/Download/Other%20Downloads/gps_instructions.pdf</ref> In 2006 the first special GPS receiver for Nikon was produced by [[Dawntech]].<ref>http://gps-camera.eu/wissen/29-hardware/202-die-anfaenge-unser-erstes-dawntech-di-gps.html</ref> Since 2009 Nikon has sold its own Geotagger GP-1. Canon uses the USB socket on the wireless file transmitter unit (WFT) as the GPS interface.
Some [[digital camera]]s and [[camera phone]]s support an external [[Global Positioning System|GPS]] receiver connected by cable, or inserted into the memory card slot or flash shoe. The Samsung SH100 can connect using [[Wi-Fi]] to get position data from a GPS-enabled [[smartphone]].<ref>{{cite web|title=CES: Samsung's SH100 Wi-Fi-enabled camera|url=http://www.macworld.com/article/156989/2011/01/samsung_sh100.html|publisher=MacWorld|date=7 January 2011}}</ref> Generally the relevant GPS data is automatically stored in the photo's [[Exchangeable image file format|Exif]] information when the photo is taken. A connected GPS will generally remain switched on continuously, requiring power, and will then have location information available immediately when the camera is switched on.
Many GPS-ready cameras are currently available, made by manufacturers such as [[Nikon]], [[Fujifilm]], [[Sony]] and [[Panasonic]]. Automatic geotagging combined with real-time transfer and publishing results in [[real-time geotagging]].
===Synchronizing with a separate GPS=== Most cameras sold today do not contain a built-in GPS receiver; however, an external location-aware device, such as a hand-held [[GPS_tracking_unit#Data_loggers|GPS logger]], can still be used with a non-GPS digital camera for geotagging. The photo is taken without geographical information and is processed later using software in conjunction with the GPS data. [[Timestamp]]s made by the camera can be compared with timestamps in the recorded GPS information, provided that the clocks in the separate devices can be synchronized. The resulting coordinates can then be added to the Exif information of the photo.
===Manual geotagging=== Location information can also be added to photos, for example via its [[Exif]] specification that has fields for longitude/latitude, even if no GPS device was present when the photo was taken.
The information can be entered by directly giving the coordinates or by selecting a location from a map using software tools. Some tools allow entry of tags such as city, [[postal code]] or a street address. [[Geocoding]] and [[reverse geocoding]] can be used to convert between locations and addresses.
Manual geotagging also introduces possibilities of error, where a photograph's location is incorrectly represented by wrong coordinates. An advanced comparative analysis of such photos with the total collection set of all photos available from the surrounding coordinates, needs to be done to single out and flag such photos, but such a software's value, need and purpose could be limited in today's environment where almost every smartphone and camera have geotagging built-in and users do not need to manually enter this information.
===Remote standoff capture=== [[File:Predator screenshot.jpg|thumb|right|Screenshot from a [[U.S. Customs and Border Protection]] [[General Atomics MQ-1 Predator|Predator UAV]], showing the GPS position of the aircraft (red) and the target (blue)]] Some manufacturers of military and professional mapping-grade GPS instruments have integrated a GPS receiver with a [[laser rangefinder]] and [[digital camera]]. These multi-functional tools are able to determine a remote subject's GPS position by calculating the subject's geographic location relative to the camera's GPS position. These instruments are commonly used in military applications when an aircraft or operator is targeting an area, the position is inaccessible (for example over a valley or wetland), there are personal health & safety concerns (motorway traffic), or the user wants to quickly capture multiple targets from a single, safe position (trees, street signage and furniture).
Civilian integrated GPS cameras with rangefinders and remote standoff capability are currently available made by manufacturers such as Ricoh and Surveylab.
==Uses== When geotagged photos are uploaded to online sharing communities such as [[Flickr]], [[Panoramio]] or [[Moblog]], the photo can be placed onto a map to view the location the photo was taken. In this way, users can browse photos from a map, search for photos from a given area, and find related photos of the same place from other users.
Many [[smartphone]]s automatically geotag their photos by default. Photographers who prefer not to reveal their location can turn this feature off.<ref>[http://www.nv.ngb.army.mil/Army%20Geotagging%20Safety.pdf US Army] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101217152857/http://www.nv.ngb.army.mil/Army%20Geotagging%20Safety.pdf |date=2010-12-17 }}</ref> Additionally smartphones can use their GPS to geotag photos taken with an external camera.
[[File:GPS_location_stamped_with_GPStamper.jpg#file|thumb|Geotagged photo location stamped with GPStamper]] Geotagged photos may be visually stamped with their GPS location information using software tools. A stamped photo affords universal and cross-platform viewing of the photo's location, and offers the security of retaining that location information in the event of metadata corruption, or if file metadata is stripped from a photo, e.g. when uploading to various online photo sharing communities.
Geotagging is also being used to determine social patterns. For example, Now app uses geotagged Instagram photos to find nearby events happening now.<ref>https://techcrunch.com/2013/01/11/now-app/</ref>
==See also== *[[Geotagging]] *[[Point of Interest]] *[[GPS tracking]] *[[Geocoding]] *[[commons:Commons:Geocoding|Geocoding on Commons]] *[[List of cameras which provide geotagging]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * {{dmoz|Science/Social_Sciences/Geography/Geographic_Information_Systems/Directories/|GIS Directories}} * {{dmoz|Science/Social_Sciences/Geography/Geographic_Information_Systems/Data/|GIS Maps}} * [http://www.geo.uzh.ch/~rsp/gir/abstracts/naaman.pdf Assigning Textual Names to Sets of Geographic Coordinates (pdf)] * [https://trixon.se/projects/mapollage/ Open source photo kml generator for Google Earth]

{{Infobox lake | name = Žalieji lakes | image = Balsys_lake.jpg | caption = Lake Balsys in spring | image_bathymetry = | caption_bathymetry = | location = [[Vilnius county]] | coords = {{coord|54|47|43|N|25|19|6|E|region:LT_type:waterbody|display=inline,title}} | type = | inflow = | outflow = | catchment = | basin_countries = [[Lithuania]] | length = | width = | area = | depth = | max-depth = {{convert|47|m|abbr=on}} | volume = | residence_time = | shore = | elevation = | islands = | cities = [[Vilnius]] }} '''Green Lakes''' (Lithuanian: ''Žalieji ežerai'') are six lakes located in northeastern part of [[Vilnius]], [[Lithuania]]. They are a part of [[Verkiai Regional Park]].
The six lakes are named: * Balsys Lake * Gulbinas Lake * Mažasis (Little) Gulbinas Lake * Akis Lake * Raistelis Lake * Baraukos Akis Lake
[[Category:Lakes of Lithuania]] [[Category:Geography of Vilnius]]

revision.comment: /* Verification of unclimbed status */m
revision.text:
{{short description|A summit never reached by mountaineers}} [[File:Batura valley Passu.jpg|right|thumb|[[Muchu Chhish]] at far left is the tallest peak on earth that is not off limits to climbers that remains still unclimbed as of 2018.]] An '''unclimbed mountain''' is a mountain peak that has yet to be climbed to the top. Determining which unclimbed peak is highest is often a matter of controversy. In some parts of the world, surveying and mapping are still unreliable, and there are no comprehensive records of the routes of explorers, mountaineers and local inhabitants. In some cases, even modern ascents by larger parties have been poorly documented and, with no universally recognized listing, the best that can be achieved in determining the world's highest unclimbed peaks is somewhat speculative. Most sources indicate that [[Gangkhar Puensum]] ({{convert|7570|m|ft}}) in [[Bhutan]] or on the Bhutan-[[China]] border is the tallest mountain in the world that has yet to be fully summited. Gangkhar Puensum has been off limits to climbers since 1994 when Bhutan prohibited all mountaineering above {{convert|6000|m|ft|abbr=on}} due to spiritual/religious beliefs.<ref name=nuwer>{{cite web|last1=Nuwer|first1=Rachel|title=The mountains we have never climbed|url=http://www.bbc.com/future/story/20140703-the-last-mountains-to-climb|publisher=BBC|accessdate=14 February 2018|date=4 July 2014}}</ref>
Unclimbed mountains are sometimes referred to as "virgin peaks". Many virgin peaks exist because the mountain is unreachable, due to either geographic isolation or political instability. Some mountains remain off limits due to religious beliefs of a country or region that hold such mountains are sacred and should remain inviolate. Additionally, since the endeavor to scale taller mountains of the world is usually a major undertaking, lesser peaks, while still very formidable, simply get less attention than the taller ones, and instead these taller peaks are summited by parties following a new route or perhaps during the winter when conditions are generally more treacherous.<ref name=nuwer/>
==Challenges in definition== ===Definition of a mountain=== [[File:prominence_definition.svg|right|thumb|250px|Figure 1. Vertical arrows show the topographic prominence of three peaks on an island. The dashed horizontal lines show the lowest contours that do not encircle higher peaks. Curved arrows point from a peak to its parent.]] Many mountains, in addition to their highest point or peak, will also have subsidiary subpeaks. Generally, the [[topographic prominence]] of a peak or subpeak, as well as the general topography, all come into consideration when determining whether such apexes are considered to be independent peaks or subpeaks. Although objective criteria have been proposed for distinguishing peaks from subpeaks, there is no widely agreed standard. In 1994, the [[International Climbing and Mountaineering Federation]] (UIAA) classified 82 mountain peaks in the [[Alps]] whose summits were at least {{convert|4000|m|abbr=on}} above sea level and with at least {{convert|30|m|abbr=on}} of topographic prominence over any adjacent [[mountain pass]] or [[col]], as a distinct peak.<ref name="uiaa">{{cite web|title=Mountain Classification|url=http://www.theuiaa.org/mountaineering/mountain-classification/|publisher=UIAA-International Climbing and Mountaineering Federation|accessdate=14 February 2018}}</ref>
===Verification of unclimbed status=== It can be difficult sometimes to determine whether or not a mountain peak has been fully summited. Long before modern mountaineering commenced in the middle of the 19th century, evidence indicates that people did indeed travel up to the summits or near to the summits of major mountain peaks. Archaeological excavations in the [[Andes]] have shown that humans travelled up to {{convert|6739|m|ft|abbr=on}} in pre-historic times.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Reinhard|first1=Johan|last2=Ceruti|first2=Constanza|title=Inca Rituals and Sacred Mountains: A Study of the World's Highest Archaeological Sites|date=2010|publisher=Institute of Archaeology Press|isbn=9781931745765}}</ref> Permanent settlements as high as {{convert|4500|m|abbr=on}} were established as long as 12,000 years ago in the Andes as well.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Ghose|first1=Tia|title=Oldest High-Altitude Human Settlement Discovered in Andes|url=https://www.livescience.com/48419-high-altitude-setllement-peru.html|publisher=Live Science|accessdate=14 March 2018|date=23 October 2014}}</ref> In the Greater Himalaya region, [[Lhasa (prefecture-level city)|Lhasa]], in Tibet, sitting at {{convert|3650|m|abbr=on}} has been permanently occupied since the 7th century and many smaller settlements across the Greater Himalaya thrive at elevations exceeding {{convert|4000|m|abbr=on}}.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Gill|first1=Nicholas|title=Where are the world's highest cities?|url=https://www.theguardian.com/cities/2016/feb/08/where-world-highest-cities-altitude|publisher=The Guardian|accessdate=14 March 2018|date=8 February 2016}}</ref> With humans living at high elevations for many millennia, nearby peaks to such settlements may or may not have been summited at some point in the past. However, many regions away from settlements may have never before been explored, especially since some high peaks in the [[Greater Ranges]] are so remote that they were unknown to local inhabitants when first sighted by European explorers.
The worlds third tallest peak, [[Kangchenjunga]], has been summited a number of times, but after the first climbers of the peak agreed to honor the wishes of locals and not set foot on the topmost part of the mountain, succeeding mountaineering parties may have followed this tradition. Similarly, [[Nanda Devi]] has also been climbed but the topmost summit was not ascended and the primary summit is now off limits to climbers. [[Machapuchare]] had only one summit attempt back in 1957 when climbers came within {{convert|150|m|abbr=on}} of the summit; Nepal then banned future attempts.<ref>{{cite web|title=The Four Forbidden Mountains in the Himalayas|url=http://climbreport.net/4-forbidden-mountains-in-the-himalayas/|publisher=Climb Report|accessdate=16 March 2018|date=6 March 2016}}</ref>
==Gangkhar Puensum== [[File:Gangkhar puensum summit.JPG|thumb|Summit of [[Gangkhar Puensum]] from Gophu La pass, [[Bhutan]]]] The mountain most widely claimed to be the highest unclimbed mountain in the world in terms of [[elevation]] is [[Gangkhar Puensum]] ({{convert|7570|m|ft|abbr=on}}).<ref name="TI_2001">{{cite journal|author=Tsuguyasu Itami|title=Gankarpunzum & First Ascent Of Liankang Kangri|journal=Japanese Alpine News|date=October 2001|volume=1|url=http://www.jac.or.jp/english/jan/vol1/GANKARPUNZUM.pdf|accessdate=14 March 2018 }}</ref> It is in [[Bhutan]], on or near the border with [[People's Republic of China|China]]. In Bhutan, the climbing of mountains higher than {{convert|6000|m|ft|abbr=on}} has been prohibited since 1994. The rationale for this prohibition is based on local customs that consider this and similar peaks to be the sacred homes of protective deities and spirits, and the lack of high-altitude rescue resources from any locale closer than [[India]]. The prohibition was further expanded in 2003 when mountaineering of any kind was disallowed entirely within Bhutan. Gangkhar Puensum will likely remain unclimbed so long as the government of Bhutan prohibits it.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Jennings|first1=Ken|title=What's The World's Highest Mountain That's Never Been Climbed|url=https://www.cntraveler.com/stories/2015-12-14/whats-the-worlds-highest-mountain-thats-never-been-climbed|publisher=Conde Nast|accessdate=14 March 2018|date=14 December 2015}}</ref>
==Highest unclimbed non-prohibited peak== [[File:Kabru2.jpg|left|thumb|A secondary summit of Kabru is one of the tallest that still remain unclimbed]] It is unclear which is the highest unclimbed non-prohibited mountain. While some recognize only peaks with {{convert|100|m|abbr=on}} of topographical prominence as individual summits, the International Climbing and Mountaineering Federation uses a {{convert|30|m|abbr=on}} as the cutoff for determining individual summits. Based on the International Climbing and Mountaineering Federation's criteria, [[Muchu Chhish]] ({{convert|7452|m|ft|abbr=on}} with a prominence of {{convert|263|m|ft|abbr=on}}) in Pakistan is currently the world's tallest that has not been climbed even though it is legal to do so. Other unclimbed summits include one on the massif known as [[Kabru]] ({{convert|7318|m|abbr=on}} prominence c. {{convert|100|m|abbr=on}}), [[Labuche Kang III/East]] ({{convert|7250|m|ft|abbr=on}}) with prominence of {{convert|570|m|abbr=on}} and [[Karjiang]] ({{convert|7221|m|ft|abbr=on}} with a prominence of {{convert|895|m|ft|abbr=on}}).<ref name="newcomb">{{cite web|last1=Newcomb|first1=Tim|title=7 of the Tallest Unclimbed Mountains in the World|url=https://www.popularmechanics.com/adventure/outdoors/g13537785/7-of-the-tallest-unclimbed-mountains-in-the-world/|publisher=Popular Mechanics|accessdate=14 March 2018|date=19 January 2018}}</ref> {{clear}}
==Most prominent unclimbed peak== Unclimbed candidates with high [[topographic prominence]] are by definition independent mountains, but some have relatively modest elevations. With such peaks there is a greater possibility of undocumented ascents, perhaps occurring long ago.
[[Sauyr Zhotasy]] ({{convert|3840|m|ft|abbr=on}}, prominence of {{convert|3252|m|ft|abbr=on}}), the highpoint in the [[Saur Mountains|Saur Range]] on the border between [[Kazakhstan]] and [[China]], and [[Mount Siple]] ({{convert|3110|m|ft|abbr=on}}, prominence of {{convert|3110|m|ft|abbr=on}}) on [[Siple Island]] off the coast of [[Antarctica]], have no record of successful ascents, but the unclimbed status of each of these peaks is difficult to confirm.<ref name=newcomb/>
== See also == * [[List of peaks by prominence]] * [[List of highest mountains]]
== References == {{reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Highest Unclimbed Mountain}} [[Category:History of mountaineering]] [[Category:Geographical superlatives]]

revision.comment: v1.43 - Repaired 3 links to disambiguation pages - [[WP:DPL|(You can help)]] - [[Celtic]], [[Crag]], [[Rock]] / [[WP:WCW]] project (Reference before punctuation)
revision.text:
{{italic title}} [[File:Loreley_LOC.jpg|thumb|The Loreley on the River Rhine, c. 1900]] [[File:Basaltstrukturen Erpeler Ley.jpg|thumb|Erpeler Ley on the Rhine]] [[File:Rabenley.jpg|thumb|The Rabenlay near Oberwesel]] '''''Ley''''' (''the Ley'', plural: the ''Leyen'') is an old German word for [[rock (geology)|rock]], [[cliff]] or [[crag (climbing)|crag]] which often occurs in placenames.
== Etymology == ''Ley'', also ''lay'', ''lei'', ''lai'', ''laige''<ref>Friedrich Woeste: ''Wörterbuch der westfälischen Mundart''. Leipzig, 1882, p. 155 ([http://reader.digitale-sammlungen.de/de/fs1/object/display/bsb11023641_00001.html online])</ref> or ''lägge'',<ref>Reinhard Pilkmann-Pohl: ''Plattdeutsches Wörterbuch des kurkölnischen Sauerlandes.'' Strobel-Verlag, Arnsberg 1988.</ref> and, accourding to Grimm, ''leie'', is a commonly occurring name for rocks or crags in the [[Rhenish]] and [[Lower German]] language regions. It is derived from the [[Old Saxon]] word, ''lêia''. It is particularly associated with rock precipices (''Felsabbrüche'') and rock faces (''Felswände''), but also with rock slabs (''Felsplatte''). In addition, it is also used in the sense of [[shale]] or [[slate]] ''(Leienstein)'', and also to mean "slate" in the sense of a blackboard or roofing tile ''([[Leyendecker|Leiendecker]])''. Its [[Dutch language|Dutch]] form is ''leyde'' or ''leye''.<ref name="Grimm-Leie"> Eintrag [http://woerterbuchnetz.de/DWB/wbgui_py?lemid=GL04319 LEIE,LEI, f. fels, stein.] In: Jacob Grimm, Wilhelm Grimm: ''[[Deutsches Wörterbuch]]''. Leipzig 1854-1960 (dwb.uni-trier.de)</ref>
According to Celtologists at the [[University of Trier]] the term may have originally come from the Gallic ([[Celtic languages|Celtic]]) word, ''lika, likka'' which means "rock slab/sheet''.<ref>[https://www.uni-trier.de/index.php?id=37329 Forum Keltic Studies zu Lei]</ref>
In addition to natural rock walls, an artificial [[quarry]], such as the basalt quarries of the [[Eifel]], may be called a ''Ley'' or ''Lay''. The workers there are known as ''Layer''.<ref>{{cite web|title=Vulkanschule: Die Museumslay|periodical=|publisher=Vulkanpark, Nationaler Geopark Vulkanland Eifel|url=http://vulkanschule.de/service/vulkanpark-stationen/museumslay|deadurl=|format=|accessdate=2015-05-26|archiveurl=|archivedate=|last=|date=|year=|month=|day=|language=German|pages=|quote=}}</ref>
== Examples == <!-- Please restrict the list to a selection of the better known sites --> * [[Loreley]], a well known slate hill on the Rhine * [[Tholey]], parish and abbey in the northern [[Saarland]] * [[Theley]], a village in the parish of [[Tholey]] * [[Erpeler Ley]], a basalt rock face above the Rhine * the Koblenz quarter of [[Koblenz-Lay|Lay]] * [[Offenbach-Kaiserlei|Kaiserlei]], a quarter in the city of Offenbach, named after a rock above the River Main * the [[Rabenlay]] is a hill in the [[Siebengebirge]] range, at the foot of which was found the double grave of Oberkassel. * the Rabenlay is a shallows in the Rhine at river kilometre 548.5-549.0 near [[Oberwesel]] * [[Lavakeller (Mendig)|Mendiger Ley]], basalt mine * [[Leybucht]] near [[Norden (East Frisia)|Norden]] ([[East Frisia]]) * [[Plästerlegge]] ("raining slate rock"), waterfall near the Bestwig village of [[Wasserfall (Bestwig)|Wasserfall]] * [[Geierlay]] in (Mörsdorf Hunsrück), Germany's second longest suspension bridge
== References == <references/>
[[Category:Rock formations of Germany|*]] [[Category:Oronyms]]

page.title: List of Grand Dukes of Bosnia

revision.text:
{{See also|List of rulers of Bosnia}} The title '''''[[Grand duke|Grand Duke]] of Bosnia''''' ({{lang-bs|Veliki Vojvoda Bosanski}}) was a court title in the [[Kingdom of Bosnia]], bestowed by the King to highest military commanders, usually reserved for most influential and most capable among highest Bosnian nobility.{{cite book |last=Fine |first=John Van Antwerp |title=The Late Medieval Balkans: A Critical Survey from the Late Twelfth Century to the Ottoman Conquest |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=QDFVUDmAIqIC&printsec=frontcover#v=onepage&q&f=false |year=1994 |publisher=University of Michigan Press |isbn=0-472-08260-4 |access-date= 20 October 2018}} To interpret it as an office post rather than a court rank could be more accurate.{{cite book|last1=Kurtović|first1=Esad|title=Veliki vojvoda bosanski Sandalj Hranić Kosača|publisher=Institut za istoriju Sarajevo|date=2009|isbn=978-9958-649-01-1|edition=Historijske monografije; knj. 4|url=http://www.iis.unsa.ba/pdf/kurtovic_sandalj_hranic_kosaca.pdf|accessdate=10 January 2016|language=Bosnian|format=.pdf}} == Grand Dukes of Bosnia == {| class="wikitable" |- ! Picture ! TitleName ! House ! Reign ! Overlordship ! Notes |- |[[File:Vukovići.png|50px]] || [[Duke]]

page.title: List of Irish place names in other countries

revision.comment: rv, Londonderry isn't a province.
revision.text:
{{see also|Place names in Ireland|List of Irish exonyms}} This is a ''partial'' or ''incomplete'' list of places in countries other than [[Ireland]] named after places in Ireland.
Massive emigration, often called the [[Irish diaspora]], from Ireland in the 19th and 20th centuries resulted in many towns and regions being named or renamed after places in Ireland.
It might be noted that the following place names sometimes share strong ties with the original place name.
== Common placenames in multiple countries == * [[Ardmore (disambiguation)|Ardmore]] **[[Ardmore, Alberta]] **[[Ardmore, New Zealand]] **[[Ardmore, Alabama]] **[[Ardmore, Maryland]] **[[Ardmore, Oklahoma]] **[[Ardmore, Pennsylvania]] **[[Ardmore, South Dakota]] **[[Ardmore, Tennessee]] * [[Dunmore (disambiguation)|Dunmore]] **[[Dunmore, Pennsylvania]] **[[Dunmore County, Virginia]] **[[Dunmore Town]], Bahamas **[[Dunmore, Alberta]], Canada **[[Dunmor, Kentucky]] * [[Erin (disambiguation)|Erin]] ** [[Erin, Tennessee]], a city in Houston County ** [[Erin, New York]], a town in Chemung County **[[Erin, Ontario]], in Wellington County **[[Erin, Wisconsin]] **[[Port Erin]], a town on the Isle of Man

revision.text:
{{EngvarB|date=May 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=May 2014}} [[File:Antigua and Barbuda-CIA WFB Map.png|thumb|right|200px|Map of Antigua and Barbuda]] There are three airports operating in [[Antigua and Barbuda]], a nation lying between the [[Caribbean Sea]] and the Atlantic Ocean. Antigua and Barbuda consists of two major inhabited islands, [[Antigua]] and [[Barbuda]], and a number of smaller islands (including Great Bird, Green, Guinea, Long, Maiden and York Islands). Separated by a few nautical miles, the group is in the middle of the [[Leeward Islands]], part of the [[Lesser Antilles]]. __TOC__ {{clear}} == Airports == '''Boldface''' indicates the airport has scheduled passenger service on commercial airlines. {| class="wikitable sortable" ! style="text-align:left;" | [[List of cities in Antigua and Barbuda|City served]] ! style="text-align:left;" | [[List of islands in the Caribbean#Antigua and Barbuda|Island]] ! style="text-align:left; width:5em;" | [[ICAO airport code|ICAO]] ! style="text-align:left; width:4em;" | [[IATA airport code|IATA]] ! style="text-align:left;" | Airport name ! style="text-align:left;" | [[Geographic coordinate system|Coordinates]] |- valign=top | [[St. John's, Antigua and Barbuda|St. John's]] | [[Antigua]] | TAPA | ANU | '''[[V. C. Bird International Airport]]''' | {{coord|17|08|12|N|61|47|34|W|type:airport|name=VC Bird International Airport}} |- valign=top | [[Codrington, Barbuda|Codrington]] | [[Barbuda]] | TAPH | BBQ | '''[[Barbuda Codrington Airport]]''' | {{coord|17|38|09|N|61|49|43|W|type:airport|name=Codrington Airport}} |- valign=top | [[Coco Point]] | [[Barbuda]] | TAPT | | [[Coco Point Lodge Airstrip]] (private) | {{coord|17|33|20|N|61|45|55|W|type:airport|name=Coco Point Lodge Airstrip}} |} == See also == {{GeoGroupTemplate}} * [[Transport in Antigua and Barbuda]] * [[List of airports by ICAO code: T#TA - Antigua and Barbuda]] * [[Wikipedia: WikiProject Aviation/Airline destination lists: North America#Antigua and Barbuda]] == References == * {{cite web | url = http://www.icao.int/safety/ism/Accident%20Incident%20Reporting%20Guidance/LocationIndicatorsByState.pdf | title = ICAO Location Indicators by State | format = [[PDF]] | publisher = [[International Civil Aviation Organization]] | date = 17 September 2010}} * {{cite web | url = http://www.unece.org/fileadmin/DAM/cefact/locode/ag.htm | title = UN Location Codes: Antigua and Barbuda | work = [[UN/LOCODE]] 2011-2 | publisher = [[United Nations Economic Commission for Europe|UNECE]] | date = 28 February 2012}} – includes IATA codes * [http://www.gcmap.com/search?Q=country:AG Great Circle Mapper: Antigua and Barbuda] – IATA codes, ICAO codes and coordinates
