revision.text:
__NOTOC__ [[File:Guam-CIA WFB Map.png|thumb|Map of Guam]] This is a list of the [[Property type (National Register of Historic Places)#Building|buildings]], [[Property type (National Register of Historic Places)#Site|sites]], [[Property type (National Register of Historic Places)#Historic districts|districts]], and [[Property type (National Register of Historic Places)#Object|objects]] listed on the '''[[National Register of Historic Places]] in [[Guam]]'''. There are currently 132 listed sites spread across 17 of the [[List of villages in Guam|19 villages of Guam]]. The villages of [[Agana Heights, Guam|Agana Heights]] and [[Mongmong-Toto-Maite, Guam|Mongmong-Toto-Maite]] do not have any listings.
Listed historic sites include Spanish colonial ruins, a few surviving pre-[[World War II]] ifil houses, Japanese fortifications, two massacre sites, and a historic district. Two other locations that were previously listed have been removed from the Register.

|date=1974-05-24 |image= |lat= |lon= |description= }} |}

revision.comment: Rescuing 6 sources and tagging 1 as dead. #IABot (v2.0beta10) ([[User:Jo-Jo Eumerus|Jo-Jo Eumerus]])
revision.text:
[[File:Ordnance Survey Drawings - St. Columb Major, Cornwall (OSD 7).jpg|thumb|right|The original draftsman's drawings for the area around [[St. Columb Major]], Cornwall, made in 1810.]] A '''national mapping agency''' is an organisation, usually publicly owned, that produces [[topographic map]]s and [[geographic data|geographic information]] of a country. Some national mapping agencies also deal with [[cadastre|cadastral]] matters. ==History== ===Ordnance Survey=== The first national mapping agency was the [[Ordnance Survey]] in the United Kingdom;{{Cite web|url=http://geospatial.blogs.com/geospatial/2012/07/ordnance-survey-forms-os-international.html|title=Ordnance Survey forms OS International to offer national mapping assistance internationally|access-date=2013-12-22|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131224111140/http://geospatial.blogs.com/geospatial/2012/07/ordnance-survey-forms-os-international.html|archive-date=2013-12-24|dead-url=no|df=}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.charlesclosesociety.org/files/Issue96page14.pdf|title=Ordnance Survey maps that changed the world|author=Nina Morgan|access-date=2013-12-22|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131224090821/http://www.charlesclosesociety.org/files/Issue96page14.pdf|archive-date=2013-12-24|dead-url=no|df=}} its roots go back to 1747, when the compilation of a map of the [[Scottish Highlands]] was proposed.By Lieutenant-Colonel David Watson to facilitate the subjugation of the clans following the [[Jacobite rising of 1745]]{{Cite journal|last=Porter|first=Whitworth|authorlink=Whitworth Porter|year=1889|title=History of the Corps of Royal Engineers|volume=I|publisher=Longmans, Green, and Co|publication-place=London|pages=167–68|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=lqlBAAAAIAAJ|accessdate=2008-08-14|postscript=|ref=harv}} This survey at a scale of 1 inch to 1000 yards (1:36,000){{Cite book|title=Maps for Historians |last=Hindle |first=Paul |year=1998 |publisher=Phillimore & Co |isbn=0-85033-934-0 |pages=114–115}} was the starting point of the [[Principal Triangulation of Great Britain]] (1783–1853), and led to the creation of the Ordnance Survey itself; work was begun in earnest in 1790, when the [[Board of Ordnance]] began a national military survey at one-[[inch]]-to-the-[[mile]] (1:63,360 scale).{{Cite book|title=Maps for Historians |last=Hindle |first=Paul |year=1998 |publisher=Phillimore & Co |isbn=0-85033-934-0 |pages=117}} During the next thirty years, roughly a third of England and Wales was mapped (see [[Principal Triangulation of Great Britain]]), as other military matters took precedence.{{Cite book|title=A History of the Ordnance Survey|editor-last=Seymour|editor-first=W.A.|year=1980|publisher=Folkestone: Wm Dawson & Sons|page=71|url=http://www.ordnancesurvey.co.uk/oswebsite/docs/ebooks/a-history-of-the-ordnance-survey/index.html|ref=harv|postscript={{inconsistent citations}}|access-date=2013-12-22|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130725142428/http://www.ordnancesurvey.co.uk/oswebsite/docs/ebooks/a-history-of-the-ordnance-survey/index.html|archive-date=2013-07-25|dead-url=no|df=}} ==List of national mapping agencies== {{Expand list|date=June 2016}} {| class="wikitable" |+ !Country or territory !National mapping agencyNames in the languages listed on the agency's website !Web site ![[Geoportal|Online map viewer]] !Notes |- | [[Afghanistan]] | [[Afghan Geodesy & Cartography Head Office]]

revision.text:
{{multiple issues| {{Orphan|date=February 2013}} {{unreferenced|date = March 2009}} }}
'''Okpofe''' is an autonomous community located in Ezinihitte Mbaise LGA, [[Imo State]], [[Nigeria]] with common boundaries with Itu, Ezeagbogu, Ihitte and Amumara autonomous communities.Okpofe is the very centre of Ezinihitte Mbaise Clan. It is the only town in Ezinihitte Mbaise that does not share a boundary with another local government area in Imo State. It is quite a unique town in Ezinihitte. Most of the general activities of Ezinihitte people hold in Okpofe due to its Central position. It is also on record that the Roman Catholic Church first established in Okpofe town in the whole of Ezinihitte Mbaise(by 2018, the town will be marking the centenary celebration of the existence of the Roman Catholic Church in Okpofe.) The Anglican Juniorate in Mbaise is located in Okpofe. Okpofe Town is a very peaceful community in Ezinihitte Mbaise. Its first traditional ruler was Late Eze Ewulonu Modestus C. Anyanka, an amiable, handsome young man who ascended the throne at the age of 42, born by an Umuimee daughter to an Okwu man. He joined his ancestors in 2005 after leading the town to an enviable height. Today, the traditional affairs of the town are under the care of His Royal Highness Eze Sir Reginald Jesse Chukwuma Aguwamba, a gentleman that is being described as "the man of the people" and whose uncle was the last warrant chief that also crowned the Late Eze Anyanka in the late 70's. Eze Reginald Aguwamba was born by an Umuimee man. (Take note of the importance of this village Umuimee in the history of Ezeship in Okpofe). A surveyor by profession, Eze Aguwamba retired voluntarily from the Owerri Capital Development Authority to serve his fatherland as the Eze Oha II. He has so far lead the community to an enviable position in the Oji Ezinihitte Festival that no other community in the clan has attained during the 2013 Oji Festival at Okpofe and the recently concluded one at Ezeagbogu. Within his first few months in office, some other developmental projects from the Imo State Government came into Okpofe. This is the sign of a good choice of traditional ruler!
The story of Okpofe cannot be complete any day without mention to Late Sydney Ngozi Njoku. He almost single-handedly financed the building of Okpofe Secondary School, Okpofe Town Hall, The Okpofe Post Office. He undertook and concluded several human and structural developmental projects in Okpofe, Ezinihitte and Imo State at large. Singoz as he was popularly called died in 1983 at a very youthful age of 42 years.
==Villages== Okpofe, which is broadly divided into two sections- Umuerim and Imoko, is made up of 12 villages namely:
* Chukwuoma * Umuafoeze * Umuocha * Umumgbadi * Okwu * Okpuala * Umuoma * Umuimee * Umuotirikpo * Dimukwu * Umuke * Okwuaba Note that this list is not in order of seniority. The first six villages belong to Imoko while the last six villages belong to Umuerim.
==MARKET== Okpofe has a central market called Afo-Ekiri Market,which is located at the centre of the entire community.It is also called Ahia Afor because it holds on Afor days.The second market which is at Umuke village is called Nkwo-onyeokamma.It holds on Nkwo days.
==Churches== The two largest churches in Okpofe are; Christ the King Catholic Church and St. Marks Anglican Church.There are also the Apostolic, Assemblies of God, Christ Chosen, Christ Faith, SDA,Cherubim and Seraphim,Christ Solution Ministry,etc.
==Schools== Okpofe Community has a secondary school (Okpofe Secondary School), and an Anglican Juniorate (Mary Sumner Juniorate) three primary schools (Central School aka CKS, Community School, and Group School Okpofe), and a private Secondary School (Bro Fab)
==Other facilities== [[Micro-finance]] [[bank]], Okpofe [[town hall]], [[health center]], [[post office]], etc. in Okpofe.
==Okpofe Improvement Union== There is an Okpofe [[Improvement Union]] (OIU) in the community with branches in: [[Port Harcourt]], [[Owerri]], [[Aba, Nigeria|Aba]], [[Enugu]], [[Lagos]], [[Onitsha]], [[Warri]], [[Calabar]], [[Makurdi]], [[Kaduna]], [[Ibadan]], [[Abuja]], [[Kano]], [[New York City]] and ODA USA. The OIU Home and Abroad has contributed to the development and improvement of the community.It is at the moment headed by Mr. Ralph Okeahialam Ntiajuka, a renowned chartered accountant of repute. The following are the Age Grades in Okpofe:
* Chikwadoro Age Grade. * Ugochukwu Age Grade. * Igwebuike Age Grade. * Ndiekwoaba Age Grade. * Ezinwanne Age Grade. * Ogueri Age Grade. * Udo-Abia Age Grade. * Ahaoma Age grade * Akurulo Age Grade * Udokamma Age Grade
[[Category:Imo State]] [[Category:Geography of Nigeria]]

revision.text:
'''Online map services of Slovenia''' are based on data provided by the [[Surveying and Mapping Authority of the Republic of Slovenia]],<ref>[http://www.gu.gov.si/en/services/data_samples/ Meta-data and samples] for data provided by the [[Surveying and Mapping Authority of the Republic of Slovenia]]</ref> such as [[orthophoto]] covering entire territory of Slovenia with detailed imagery taken from a plane rather than satellite, and combine them with additional contents that are of interest to tourists and residents of [[Slovenia]]. Orthophoto images are taken every second year and provide more detailed aerial view of entire territory whereas satellite imagery shown by Google Maps only use detailed images for city areas and along major roads, but not for the entire territory. This is why orthophoto images are cited by geographers to show environmental change, rather than images taken by satellites that are shown on Google Maps.<ref>{{cite book |last=Brilly |first=M. |title=Hydrological Processes of the Danube River Basin (citing Geopedia.si)|publisher=Springer |year=2010 |ISBN=9789048134229}}</ref>
'''Najdi.si''' combines orthophoto maps (despite its aerial view tab being named "satellite") with other contents, such as traffic info, city bus lines for Ljubljana and Maribor, and current info on the number of available bikes at [[BicikeLJ]] stations in Ljubljana.
'''Geopedia.si'''<ref>{{cite book |last1=Perko |first1=D. |last2=Zorn |first2=M. |title=Geografski informacijski sistemi v Sloveniji 2009–2010 (Geographical Information Systems in Slovenia 2009-2010)|publisher=Institut of Geography at Slovene Academy of Sciences and Arts |location = Ljubljana |year=2010 |ISBN=9789612542108}}</ref> offers a number of maps, including: *city maps from 19th century and architectural heritage in Ljubljana on geolocated 19th century postcards with comments from the book ''A pictorial chronicle of a capital city'',<ref>City maps from 19th century and architectural heritage in Ljubljana on [http://www.geopedia.si/lite.jsp?locale=en&params=T1614_x462121_y100823_s16_b4#T1614_x462121_y100823_s16_b4 geolocated 19th century postcards] with comments from the book ''A pictorial chronicle of a capital city''.</ref> *interactive archaeological map of [[Emona]] on top of (orthophoto) map of Ljubljana,<ref>[http://www.geopedia.si/lite.jsp?locale=en&params=T1513_x461784_y100467_s17_b2#T1513_x461784_y100467_s17_b2 Interactive archaeological map] of [[Emona]] on top of the (orthophoto) map of Ljubljana</ref> *cultural places of interest, *cultural events (in museums etc.) happening in the next 7 days, *paragliding info mapping service,<ref>[http://paragliding.geopedia.si/en/paragliding_sites_search.php Paragliding info] mapping service</ref> *online natural hazards monitoring mapping service.<ref>Online [http://naravnenesrece.geopedia.si/#G natural hazards monitoring] mapping service</ref>
==References== <references />
[[Category:Geography of Slovenia]] [[Category:Internet in Slovenia]] [[Category:Web mapping]]

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=January 2017}} {{Infobox launch pad | name = Rocket Lab Launch Complex 1 | image = File:Rocket Lab Launch Complex 1 (Sept 2016).jpg | imsize = 300px | caption = Launch Complex 1 on Mahia Peninsula | location = [[Mahia Peninsula]], [[New Zealand]] | coordinates = {{coord|39.2609|S|177.8655|E|display=inline,title|dim:500_region:NZ-HKB_type:landmark}} | time_zone = [[Time in New Zealand|NZST]] | utc_offset = +12 | time_zone_DST = [[Time in New Zealand|NZDT]]{{efn|Summer time is active from the last Sunday in September until the first Sunday in April.}} | utc_offset_DST = +13 | operator = [[Rocket Lab]] | pads = 1 | inclination = <!-- range of inclinations --> | paddetails = {{Infobox launch pad/pad | status = Active | launches = 3 | first_launch = {{start-date|25 May 2017}}<ref name="sfnow20170525">{{cite news |url=https://spaceflightnow.com/2017/05/25/maiden-flight-of-rocket-labs-small-satellite-launcher-reaches-space/ |title=Maiden flight of Rocket Lab’s small satellite launcher reaches space |work=Spaceflight Now |first=Stephen |last=Clark |date=25 May 2017 |accessdate=25 May 2017}}</ref> | last_launch = <!-- Date of the most recent launch from the pad --> | rockets = [[Electron (rocket)|Electron]] }} }}
'''Rocket Lab Launch Complex 1''' is a commercial [[spaceport]] located close to [[Ahuriri Point]] at the southern tip of [[Mahia Peninsula]], on the east coast of [[New Zealand]]'s [[North Island]]. It is owned and operated by [[private spaceflight]] company [[Rocket Lab]] and will support launches of the company's [[Electron (rocket)|Electron]] rocket for [[CubeSat]] nanosatellites. The facility officially opened on 26 September 2016 ([[UTC]]).
== Description == Launch Complex 1 features a {{convert|50|t|adj=on}} launch platform and tower, a hangar for the Electron rockets, and storage tanks for [[liquid oxygen]] and [[kerosene]].<ref name="latimes20160926">{{cite news |url=http://www.latimes.com/business/la-fi-rocket-lab-20160926-snap-story.html |title=Rocket Lab finishes launch complex in New Zealand |work=Los Angeles Times |first=Samantha |last=Masunaga |date=26 September 2016 |accessdate=26 September 2016}}</ref> During the test phase of launch operations, which began in May 2017,<ref name="sfnow20170525" /><ref name="roclab20161213">{{cite web |url=http://rocketlab.co.nz/latest/rocket-lab-completes-final-major-technical-milestone-before-first-test-launches/ |title=Rocket Lab Completes Major Technical Milestone Ahead of Test Launches |publisher=Rocket Lab |date=13 December 2016 |accessdate=13 December 2016}}</ref> the [[exclusion zone]] would likely be an {{convert|8|km|mi|0|adj=on|spell=on}} radius from the pad, and would reduce in size once the site became commercially operational.<ref name="nzherald20160927" />
== History == === Site options === Rocket Lab announced on 1 July 2015 that it had selected [[Kaitorete Spit]] in New Zealand's [[South Island]] near [[Canterbury, New Zealand|Canterbury]] as the site of the launch facility for its [[Electron (rocket)|Electron]] rocket, and that it hoped to have construction finished by the end of the year. While the site would not permit equatorial launches due to the presence of [[Banks Peninsula]] to the east, it was favourable for [[Sun-synchronous orbit]]al flights, which the company believed would be of primary interest to its customers. The site was also logistically favourable as the company wanted to build a rocket production facility in nearby [[Christchurch]].<ref name="spacenews20150601">{{cite news |url=http://spacenews.com/rocket-lab-selects-new-zealand-launch-site/ |title=Rocket Lab Selects New Zealand Launch Site |work=SpaceNews |first=Jeff |last=Foust |date=1 July 2015 |accessdate=26 September 2016}}</ref>
The [[Mahia Peninsula]] site at Onenui Station was mentioned in August 2015 as a possible second launch facility.<ref name="gisborne20150820">{{cite news |url=http://gisborneherald.co.nz/localnews/1900032-135/wairoa-gateway-to-the-galaxy |title='Wairoa - Gateway to the Galaxy' |work=The Gisborne Herald |date=20 August 2015 |accessdate=26 September 2016}}</ref> It had first been visited by company officials in April 2015 as part of their initial scouting for launch sites,<ref name="gisborne20151014">{{cite news |url=http://gisborneherald.co.nz/localnews/1972121-135/rocket-lab-planning-all-go-at |title=Rocket Lab planning all go at Mahia |work=Wairoa Star ''via'' The Gisborne Herald |first=Suzi |last=Lewis |date=14 October 2015 |accessdate=26 September 2016}}</ref> and were preparing to submit a [[resource consent]] application.<ref name="gisborne20150820" /> By mid-October, the application had been approved by the [[Wairoa]] District Council and [[Hawke's Bay Region|Hawke's Bay]] Regional Council only seven days after its submission,<ref name="gisborne20151014" /><ref name="nzherald20160628">{{cite news |url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/business/news/article.cfm?c_id=3&objectid=11664807 |title=All set for lift off on Mahia Peninsula |work=Hawke's Bay Today ''via'' New Zealand Herald |first=Victoria |last=White |date=28 June 2016 |accessdate=26 September 2016}}</ref> with the [[Gisborne, New Zealand|Gisborne]] Chamber of Commerce and the Eastland Community Trust working with Rocket Lab to support its bid for the Mahia site.<ref name="gisborne20151124">{{cite news |url=http://gisborneherald.co.nz/localnews/2028761-135/rocket-lab-chooses-mahia-for-space |title=Rocket Lab chooses Mahia for space launches |work=The Gisborne Herald |first1=Debbie |last1=Gregory |first2=Andrew |last2=Ashton |date=24 November 2015 |accessdate=26 September 2016}}</ref>
=== Decision for Mahia === On 23 November 2015, Rocket Lab stated that the Mahia Peninsula site would be the priority launch facility because of delays in [[Regulatory agency|obtaining resource consents for developing]] at Kaitorete Spit.<ref name="gisborne20151124" />
While certain authorisations had been obtained for Kaitorete, such as stormwater and air discharge permits from Environment Canterbury, a coastal permit for occupation of the area, and a Department of Conservation permit, the Christchurch City Council had not consented to the development due to an incomplete Cultural Impact Assessment, resulting in no action under Sections 95 and 104 of the [[Resource Management Act 1991]].<ref name="stuff20151122">{{cite news |url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/business/73935090/Kaitorete-Spit-on-the-back-burner-for-Rocket-Lab-launch |title=Canty's Birdlings Flat on the back burner for Rocket Lab launch |website=[[Stuff.co.nz]] |first=Martin |last=Van Beynen |date=22 November 2015 |accessdate=26 September 2016}}</ref> The company said that efforts would continue to gain consent for a launch pad on Kaitorete Spit due to its logistical superiority and the foreseen need for additional facilities, but that the Mahia site offered superior launch corridor and flight rate opportunities because of its geographical location and relatively sparse air traffic. The Mahia site is licensed for a maximum launch rate of once every 72 hours over a period of 30 years—Rocket Lab believes the actual rate would average once per week—while the Kaitorete site would only have been licensed to launch once per month.<ref name="stuff20151122" /><ref name="space20160926">{{cite news |url=http://www.space.com/34195-rocket-lab-opens-private-launch-site-new-zealand.html |title=Rocket Lab Opens Private Orbital Launch Site in New Zealand |work=Space.com |first=Calla |last=Cofield |date=26 September 2016 |accessdate=26 September 2016}}</ref>
The company broke ground at Mahia in December 2015, and by June 2016 most of the infrastructure work had been completed, including upgrades to roads and internet services, and work was progressing on the electrical, mechanical and communications infrastructure.<ref name="nzherald20160628" /> Rocket Lab signed an agreement with [[air traffic service]] provider [[Airways New Zealand]] in early September 2016 to develop "special use airspace" and ensure regular flight activity, which the company estimates could be up to 100 launches per year.<ref name="stuff20160909">{{cite news |url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/business/84057531/Airways-hopes-Rocket-Lab-launch-will-be-first-of-many |title=Airways hopes Rocket Lab launch will be 'first of many' |website=Stuff.co.nz |first=Hamish |last=McNicol |date=9 September 2016 |accessdate=26 September 2016}}</ref>
The Mahia Peninsula site, named Rocket Lab Launch Complex 1, was officially opened on 26 September 2016 ([[UTC]]) in a ceremony presided over by [[Ministry of Business, Innovation and Employment|Minister for Economic Development]] [[Steven Joyce]]. It was attended by approximately 240 people, including company employees, local landowners, and [[New Zealand Labour Party|Labour Party]] leader [[Andrew Little (New Zealand politician)|Andrew Little]].<ref name="nzherald20160927">{{cite news |url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/business/news/article.cfm?c_id=3&objectid=11717676 |title=Rocket launch site officially opened |work=Hawke's Bay Today ''via'' New Zealand Herald |first=Victoria |last=White |date=27 September 2016 |accessdate=27 September 2016}}</ref><ref name=spaceflightinsider-20160930 />
=== Launch history === {{main article|Electron (rocket)}} Rocket Lab carried out the first test flight of its Electron rocket, named "It's a Test", on 25 May 2017 at 04:20 [[UTC]], coming after three delays caused by bad weather during a launch window that extended from 21 May to 1 June.<ref name="sfnow20170525" /><ref name="techcrh20170514">{{cite news |url=https://techcrunch.com/2017/05/14/rocket-labs-test-launch-window-for-its-private-orbital-complex-begins-may-21/ |title=Rocket Lab’s test launch window for its private orbital complex begins May 21 |work=TechCrunch |first=Darrell |last=Etherington |date=14 May 2017 |accessdate=26 May 2017}}</ref> While lift-off from Launch Complex 1 was successful, the rocket failed to reach its intended {{convert|300|to|500|km|mi|abbr=on}} [[Sun-synchronous orbit]], only making it to about {{convert|155|mi|km|order=flip|round=5|abbr=on}}.<ref name="latimes20170525">{{cite news |url=http://www.latimes.com/business/la-fi-rocket-lab-test-20170524-story.html |title=Rocket Lab's Electron rocket reaches space, but not orbit, in first test flight |work=Los Angeles Times |first=Samantha |last=Masunaga |date=25 May 2017 |accessdate=26 May 2017}}</ref>
The second launch from the [[launch mount]] was made 21 January 2018 at 01:43 UTC, successfully making it to orbit. The Electron rocket, named "Still Testing", carried a Dove Pioneer satellite for [[Planet Labs]], two Lemur-2 satellites for [[Spire Global]] and the [[Humanity Star]].<ref name=nzh20180121>{{cite news |url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/business/news/article.cfm?c_id=3&objectid=11979201 |title=Blast off! Rocket Lab successfully reaches orbit |work=[[The New Zealand Herald]] |last=Ryan |first=Holly |date=21 January 2018 |access-date=21 January 2018}}</ref><ref name="sfnow20180121">{{cite news |url=https://spaceflightnow.com/2018/01/21/rocket-lab-delivers-nanosatellites-to-orbit-on-first-successful-test-launch/ |title=Rocket Lab delivers nanosatellites to orbit on first successful test launch |work=Spaceflight Now |first=Stephen |last=Clark |date=21 January 2018 |accessdate=21 January 2018}}</ref>
== Footnotes == {{notelist}}
== References == {{reflist|30em|refs= <ref name=spaceflightinsider-20160930>{{cite web |url=http://www.spaceflightinsider.com/missions/commercial/worlds-first-private-orbital-launch-complex-completed-in-new-zealand/ |title=World’s first private orbital launch complex completed in New Zealand |first=Tomasz |last=Nowakowski |date=30 September 2016 |publisher=Spaceflight Insider |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161001144931/http://www.spaceflightinsider.com/missions/commercial/worlds-first-private-orbital-launch-complex-completed-in-new-zealand/ |archive-date=1 October 2016 |access-date=3 October 2016}}</ref> }}
== External links == * [https://rocketlabusa.com/ Rocket Lab website]
{{Spaceport}}

page.title: Sociedad Mexicana de Geografía y Estadística

revision.comment: reverting InternetArchiveBot error
revision.text:
{{No footnotes|date=October 2013}} '''Sociedad Mexicana de Geografía y Estadística''' ('''Mexican Society for Geography and Statistics''') is a national organization founded on 18 April 1833 to promote the mapping and boundary demarcation of the [[History of Mexico#First Republic|newly independent Mexican state]]. The aim of its founders was to aid a number of governmental agencies and through the efforts of liberal head of state, [[Valentín Gómez Farías]]. It was the first geographical society in the Americas and the fourth in the world.
From the beginning, the scope of projects was very broad, covering not only the physiography of the territory but also its natural resources and their potential for development. Also included in their study was the nature of the population, its size, age distribution, ethnic and linguistic makeup. One of the first publications was in 1850, the work of geographer Antonio García Cubas, followed by an atlas of the republic, started in 1841 and completed in 1850, but not published for several years due to lack of funds.
Among the achievements of the Society were: * Initiatives within the Mexican government to issue laws providing a process for determining the official names of cities and towns. * Promoted legislation for the care of forests and conservation of archaeological monuments as a national priority. * Produced a report on the metric system, which allowed Mexico to be among the first countries in Latin America to adopt it. * Proposed the laying out of a telegraph system for Mexico City. * Sponsoring the publication of the ''Boletín de la Sociedad Mexicana de Geografía y Estadística'' (Bulletin of the Society) for the dissemination of all the reports and data that the Society accumulated.
Currently the Society contributes to the research, analysis and understanding of the major problems of Mexico through its 55 specialized academies and local societies involved in the various Mexican states. This includes close ties with [[Instituto Nacional de Estadística y Geografía]] (INEGI), and working with the various Mexican universities as well as with major [[United States|U.S.]] institutions.
==Notable presidents== * 1839-1846, 1848-1850, and 1853 [[Juan Almonte|Juan Nepomuceno Almonte]] * 1861 [[Miguel Lerdo de Tejada]] * 1881-1889 [[Ignacio Manuel Altamirano]] * 1934, 1944, and 1946 [[Jesús Silva Herzog]] * 1959 [[Isidro Fabela]]
==References== * Peña, Sergio de la and Wilkie, James W. (1994) ''La Estadística Económica en México: Los Orígenes'' (''Economic Statistics in Mexico: The Origins'') Siglo Veintiuno Editores, Universidad Autónoma Metropolitana-Azcapotzalco, Mexico City, {{ISBN|968-23-1897-1}} * Dunbar, Gary S. (1988) ""The Compass Follows the Flag": The French Scientific Mission to Mexico, 1864-1867" ''Annals of the Association of American Geographers'' 78(2): pp. 229–240, especially 233-234
==External links== * [http://smge-mexico.blogspot.com/ Blog de la Sociedad Mexicana de Geografía y Estadística]. * [http://www.smge.com.mx/ Official website of the Sociedad Mexicana de Geografía y Estadística], in Spanish * [https://web.archive.org/web/20091027024416/http://mx.geocities.com/smgedf/presidentes.htm List of presidents of the Sociedad Mexicana de Geografía y Estadística], in Spanish {{Clear}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Sociedad Mexicana de Geografia y Estadistica}} [[Category:Geographic societies]] [[Category:Scientific organizations based in Mexico]] [[Category:Organizations established in 1833]] [[Category:Geography of Mexico]]

revision.comment: /* External links */
revision.text:
{{short description|Southern point where the Earth's axis of rotation intersects its surface}} {{About|the Geographic South Pole}} {{pp-move-indef}} {{Coord|90|S|180|E|display=title}} [[Image:Geographic Southpole crop.jpg|thumb|upright=1.25|The Geographic South Pole is marked by the stake on the right.]] [[Image:Antarctica 6400px from Blue Marble.jpg|thumb|upright=1.4|[[NASA]] image showing Antarctica and the South Pole in 2005.]] [[Image:Pole-south.gif|thumb|upright=1.4|{{ordered list |South Geographic Pole |[[South Magnetic Pole]] (2007) |[[South Geomagnetic Pole]] (2005) |[[Pole of Inaccessibility|South Pole of Inaccessibility]]}}]]
The '''South Pole''', also known as the '''Geographic South Pole''' or '''Terrestrial South Pole''', is one of the two points where the [[Earth's rotation|Earth's axis of rotation]] intersects its surface. It is the southernmost point on the surface of the [[Earth]] and lies on the opposite side of the Earth from the [[North Pole]].
Situated on the continent of [[Antarctica]], it is the site of the [[United States]] [[Amundsen–Scott South Pole Station]], which was established in 1956 and has been permanently staffed since that year. The Geographic South Pole is distinct from the [[South Magnetic Pole]], the position of which is defined based on the Earth's magnetic field. The South Pole is at the center of the [[Southern Hemisphere]].
==Geography== [[Image:Ceremonial South Pole.jpg|thumb|The Ceremonial South Pole in 1998.]] [[Image:Amundsen-scott-south pole station 2007.jpg|thumb|The Ceremonial South Pole as of February 2008.]] For most purposes, the Geographic South Pole is defined as the southern point of the two points where the Earth's [[axis of rotation]] intersects its surface (the other being the [[North Pole|Geographic North Pole]]). However, the Earth's axis of rotation is actually subject to very small "wobbles" ([[polar motion]]), so this definition is not adequate for very precise work.
The [[geographic coordinate]]s of the South Pole are usually given simply as 90°S, since its longitude is geometrically undefined and irrelevant. When a longitude is desired, it may be given as {{nowrap|0°.}} At the South Pole, all directions face north. For this reason, directions at the Pole are given relative to "grid north", which points northwards along the [[prime meridian]].<ref>[http://quest.nasa.gov/antarctica/background/cara/movpole.html "Moving the South Pole"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110716140440/http://quest.nasa.gov/antarctica/background/cara/movpole.html |date=2011-07-16 }}, NASA Quest</ref> Along tight latitude circles, clockwise is east, and counterclockwise is west, opposite to the [[North Pole]].
The Geographic South Pole is located on the continent of [[Antarctica]] (although this has not been the case for all of [[History of Earth|Earth's history]] because of [[continental drift]]). It sits atop a featureless, barren, windswept and icy plateau at an altitude of 2,835 metres (9,301 ft) above sea level, and is located about 1,300 km (800 mi) from the nearest open sea at [[Bay of Whales]]. The ice is estimated to be about 2,700 metres (9,000 ft) thick at the Pole, so the land surface under the [[ice sheet]] is actually near sea level.<ref name="autogenerated1">[https://www.nsf.gov/od/opp/support/southp.jsp Amundsen–Scott South Pole Station], National Science Foundation, Office of Polar Programs</ref>
The polar ice sheet is moving at a rate of roughly 10 metres per year in a direction between 37° and 40° west of grid north,<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.southpolestation.com/pole/survey.html | title=Where is the real Pole really? | accessdate=2008-03-25 }}</ref> down towards the [[Weddell Sea]]. Therefore, the position of the station and other artificial features relative to the geographic pole gradually shift over time.
The Geographic South Pole is marked by a stake in the ice alongside a small sign; these are repositioned each year in a ceremony on [[New Year's Day]] to compensate for the movement of the ice.<ref name=antarcticsun2006>[http://antarcticsun.usap.gov/pastIssues/2005-2006/2006_01_08.pdf "Marker makes annual move"], page 6, Antarctic Sun. January 8, 2006; McMurdo Station, Antarctica.</ref> The sign records the respective dates that [[Roald Amundsen]] and [[Robert Falcon Scott|Robert F. Scott]] reached the Pole, followed by a short quotation from each man, and gives the elevation as "9,301 ''FT.''"<!-- Please do not convert this number to metres. The sign gives the elevation in feet -->.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.classicalarchives.com/prs/astro/Antarctica/0640-Sign_at_the__moving__actual_geographical_South_Pole.jpg |title=Sign at the (ever moving) actual geographical South Pole (a few feet away from the Ceremonial Pole) |publisher=Pierre R. Schwob Physics/Astronomy |accessdate=2013-05-25}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.trekearth.com/gallery/photo284509.htm | author=Kiefer, Alex | title=South Pole Marker |date=January 1994 | accessdate=2008-03-24 }}</ref> A new marker stake is designed and fabricated each year by staff at the site.<ref name=antarcticsun2006/>
===Ceremonial South Pole=== The Ceremonial South Pole is an area set aside for photo opportunities at the [[Amundsen–Scott South Pole Station|South Pole Station]]. It is located some meters from the Geographic South Pole, and consists of a metallic sphere on a short bamboo pole, surrounded by the flags of the original [[Antarctic Treaty]] signatory [[Sovereign state|states]].{{cn|date=January 2018}}
===Historic monuments=== [[File:Saludo a la Bandera Argentina durante la Operación 90.jpg|thumb|right|Argentinian soldiers saluting the flag after erecting the pole in 1965.]]
'''Amundsen's Tent''': The tent was erected by the Norwegian expedition led by Roald Amundsen on its arrival on 14 December 1911. It is currently buried beneath the snow and ice in the vicinity of the Pole. It has been designated a [[Historic Sites and Monuments in Antarctica|Historic Site or Monument]] (HSM 80), following a proposal by Norway to the [[Antarctic Treaty System|Antarctic Treaty Consultative Meeting]].<ref name=atcm>{{cite web |url= http://www.ats.aq/documents/ATCM35/WW/atcm35_ww003_e.pdf|title= List of Historic Sites and Monuments approved by the ATCM (2012)|accessdate=2014-01-07 |publisher=Antarctic Treaty Secretariat |year=2012}}</ref> The precise location of the tent is unknown, but based on calculations of the rate of movement of the ice and the accumulation of snow, it is believed, as of 2010, to lie between 1.8 and 2.5 km (1.1 and 1.6 miles) from the Pole at a depth of 17 m (56 ft) below the present surface.<ref>[http://journals.cambridge.org/action/displayAbstract;jsessionid=413DE249464BAEBDBF64B335F6B5C576.journals?fromPage=online&aid=8295706] ''Polar Record'' / Volume 47 / Issue 03 / July 2011</ref>
'''Argentine Flagpole''': A [[flag#Flagpoles|flagpole]] erected at the South Geographical Pole in December 1965 by the [[Operación 90|First Argentine Overland Polar Expedition]] has been designated a [[Historic Sites and Monuments in Antarctica|Historic Site or Monument]] (HSM 1) following a proposal by Argentina to the [[Antarctic Treaty System|Antarctic Treaty Consultative Meeting]].<ref name=ats>{{cite web |url= http://www.ats.aq/documents/ATCM35/WW/atcm35_ww003_e.pdf|title= List of Historic Sites and Monuments approved by the ATCM (2012)|accessdate=2013-10-04 |publisher=Antarctic Treaty Secretariat |year=2012}}</ref>
==Exploration== {{see also|History of Antarctica|List of Antarctic expeditions|Heroic Age of Antarctic Exploration|Farthest South}}
===Pre-1900=== In 1820, several expeditions claimed to have been the first to have sighted Antarctica, with the very first{{clarify | reason = Very first what? Claim or sighting?|date=September 2016}} being the Russian expedition led by [[Fabian Gottlieb von Bellingshausen]] and [[Mikhail Lazarev]].<ref>{{cite journal |date=1971 |title=Bellingshausen and the discovery of Antarctica|journal=Polar Record |volume=15 |issue=99 |pages=887–889 |doi=10.1017/S0032247400062112 |last1=Armstrong|first1=Terence}}</ref> The first landing was probably just over a year later when American Captain John Davis, a sealer, set foot on the ice.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Hurtigruten|title=General Information|url=http://people.rit.edu/~msl7852/webdesign/midterm/antarctica.html|website=hurtigruten.com/us/|publisher=Hurtigruten|accessdate=2014-10-23|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141023171055/http://people.rit.edu/~msl7852/webdesign/midterm/antarctica.html|archivedate=2014-10-23|df=}}</ref>
The basic geography of the Antarctic coastline was not understood until the mid-to-late 19th century. American naval officer [[Charles Wilkes]] claimed (correctly) that Antarctica was a new continent, basing the claim on his exploration in 1839–40,<ref>{{cite book|author1=Van Doren, Charles Lincoln |author2=McHenry, Robert |title=Webster's Guide to American History: A Chronological, Geographical, and Biographical Survey and Compendium|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=MVU6DS6Re8gC&pg=PA1326+|year=1971|publisher=Merriam-Webster|isbn=978-0-87779-081-5|page=1326}}</ref> while [[James Clark Ross]], in his expedition of 1839–43, hoped that he might be able to sail all the way to the South Pole. (He was unsuccessful.)<ref>{{cite book|author=Berkman, Paul Arthur |title=Science Into Policy: Global Lessons from Antarctica|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=LDiGTYXZ9X4C&pg=PA35+|year=2002|publisher=Academic Press|isbn=978-0-12-091560-6|page=35}}</ref>
===1900–1950=== [[File:Aan de Zuidpool - p1913-160.jpg|thumb|Amundsen's party at the South Pole, December 1911. From left to right: [[Roald Amundsen|Amundsen]], [[Helmer Hanssen|Hanssen]], [[Sverre Hassel|Hassel]] and [[Oscar Wisting|Wisting]] (photo by fifth member [[Olav Bjaaland|Bjaaland]]).]]
British explorer [[Robert Falcon Scott]] on the [[Discovery Expedition]] of 1901–04 was the first to attempt to find a route from the Antarctic coastline to the South Pole. Scott, accompanied by [[Ernest Shackleton]] and [[Edward Adrian Wilson|Edward Wilson]], set out with the aim of travelling as far south as possible, and on 31 December 1902, reached 82°16′ S.<ref>{{cite book|author=Berkman, Paul Arthur |title=Science Into Policy: Global Lessons from Antarctica|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=LDiGTYXZ9X4C&pg=PA37|year=2002|publisher=Academic Press|isbn=978-0-12-091560-6|page=37}}</ref> Shackleton later returned to Antarctica as leader of the British Antarctic Expedition ([[Nimrod Expedition]]) in a bid to reach the Pole. On 9 January 1909, with three companions, he reached 88°23' S – {{Convert|112|mi|km}} from the Pole – before being forced to turn back.<ref>{{cite book|author=Simpson-Housley, Paul |title=Antarctica: Exploration, Perception and Metaphor|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=M1ql3mx8xYgC&pg=PA24|date= 2002|publisher=Taylor & Francis|isbn=978-0-203-03602-0|page=24}}</ref>
The first men to reach the Geographic South Pole were the [[Norway|Norwegian]] [[Amundsen's South Pole expedition|Roald Amundsen and his party]] on December 14, 1911. Amundsen named his camp [[Polheim]] and the entire plateau surrounding the Pole ''[[King Haakon VII Vidde]]'' in honour of King [[Haakon VII of Norway]]. Robert Falcon Scott returned to Antarctica with his second expedition, the [[Terra Nova Expedition]], initially unaware of Amundsen's secretive expedition. Scott and four other men reached the South Pole on January 17, 1912, thirty-four days after Amundsen. On the return trip, Scott and his four companions all died of starvation and extreme cold.
In 1914 Ernest Shackleton's [[Imperial Trans-Antarctic Expedition]] set out with the goal of crossing Antarctica via the South Pole, but his ship, the ''[[Endurance (1912 ship)|Endurance]]'', was frozen in [[Sea ice|pack ice]] and sank 11 months later. The overland journey was never made.
US Admiral [[Richard Evelyn Byrd]], with the assistance of his first pilot [[Bernt Balchen]], became the first person to fly over the South Pole on November 29, 1929.
===1950–present=== [[Image:SPSM.05.jpg|thumb|[[Amundsen–Scott South Pole Station]].
The ceremonial pole and flags can be seen in the background, slightly to the left of centre, below the tracks behind the buildings. The actual geographic pole is a few more metres to the left. The buildings are raised on stilts to prevent snow build up.]] It was not until 31 October 1956 that humans once again set foot at the South Pole, when a party led by Admiral [[George J. Dufek]] of the US Navy landed there in an R4D-5L Skytrain ([[C-47 Skytrain]]) aircraft. The US [[Amundsen–Scott South Pole Station]] was established by air over 1956–1957 for the [[International Geophysical Year]] and has been continuously staffed since then by research and support personnel.<ref name="autogenerated1"/>
After Amundsen and Scott, the next people to reach the South Pole ''overland'' (albeit with some air support) were [[Edmund Hillary]] (January 4, 1958) and [[Vivian Fuchs]] (January 19, 1958) and their respective parties, during the [[Commonwealth Trans-Antarctic Expedition]]. There have been many subsequent expeditions to arrive at the South Pole by surface transportation, including those by Havola, [[Albert P. Crary|Crary]] and [[Ranulph Twistleton-Wykeham Fiennes|Fiennes]]. The first group of women to reach the pole were Pam Young, Jean Pearson, [[Lois Jones (scientist)|Lois Jones]], Eileen McSaveney, Kay Lindsay and Terry Tickhill in 1969.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.southpolestation.com/trivia/igy2/welch/jones.html|title=First Women at Pole|last=|first=|date=|website=South Pole Station|publisher=|access-date=24 August 2016}}</ref> In 1978-79 Michele Eileen Raney became the first woman to winter at the South Pole.<ref name=":3">{{Cite web|url=http://antarcticsun.usap.gov/features/contentHandler.cfm?id=1954|title=Famous Firsts|last=|first=|date=13 November 2009|website=The Antarctic Sun|publisher=United States Antarctic Program|access-date=25 August 2016}}</ref>
Subsequent to the establishment, in 1987, of the logistic support base at [[Patriot Hills Base Camp]], the South Pole became more accessible to non-government expeditions.
On December 30, 1989, [[Arved Fuchs]] and [[Reinhold Messner]] were the first to traverse Antarctica via the South Pole without animal or motorized help, using only skis and the help of wind.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.suedtirol.info/South_Tyrol/Detail_Famous_persons/D-1208-en-Reinhold_Messner.html |title=Südtirol – Diese Seite existiert nicht |publisher=Suedtirol.info |accessdate=2012-08-13 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120310043609/http://www.suedtirol.info/South_Tyrol/Detail_Famous_persons/D-1208-en-Reinhold_Messner.html |archivedate=March 10, 2012 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.britannica.com/facts/5/263444/Antarctica-as-discussed-in-Reinhold-Messner-Italian-explorer |title=Britannica Online Encyclopedia |work=Encyclopædia Britannica |accessdate=2012-08-13}}{{dead link|date=May 2013}}</ref> Two women, [[Tori Murden|Victoria E. Murden]] and Shirley Metz reached the pole by land on January 17, 1989.<ref name=":2">{{Cite web|url=http://www.antarctic-circle.org/firsts.htm|title=Antarctic Firsts|last=|first=|date=4 October 2014|website=Antarctic Circle|publisher=|access-date=24 August 2016}}</ref>
The fastest unsupported journey to the Geographic South Pole from the ocean is 24 days and one hour from [[Hercules Inlet]] and was set in 2011 by Norwegian adventurer Christian Eide,<ref>{{cite news|author=Explorersweb |url=http://www.explorersweb.com/polar/news.php?id=19887 |title=Breaking news: Christian Eide bags the South Pole solo speed ski world record |publisher=explorersweb.com |date=2011-01-13 |accessdate=2011-01-13}}</ref> who beat the previous solo record set in 2009 by American [[Todd Carmichael]] of 39 days and seven hours, and the previous group record also set in 2009 of 33 days and 23 hours.<ref>{{cite news|agency=The Canadian Press |url=https://www.thestar.com/News/Canada/article/563312 |title=Canadians break speed record trekking to South Pole |work=Toronto Star |date=2009-01-07 |accessdate=2010-02-10}}</ref>
The fastest solo (female), unsupported and unassisted trek to the south pole was performed by [[Hannah McKeand]] from the UK in 2006. She made the journey in 39 days 9hrs 33mins. She started on the 19th November 2006 and finished on the 28 December 2006.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Guinness World Records 2014|last=Glenday|first=Craig|publisher=The Jim Patison Group|year=2013|isbn=978-1-908843-15-9|location=|pages=76|quote=|via=}}</ref>
In the 2011/12 summer, separate expeditions by Norwegian [[Aleksander Gamme]] and Australians [[Cas and Jonesy|James Castrission and Justin Jones]] jointly claimed the first unsupported trek without dogs or kites from the Antarctic coast to the South Pole and back. The two expeditions started from [[Hercules Inlet]] a day apart, with Gamme starting first, but completing according to plan the last few kilometres together. As Gamme traveled alone he thus simultaneously became the first to complete the task solo.<ref>{{cite web|title=Ice Trek Expeditions|url=http://www.icetrek.com/?id=432|accessdate=2013-05-25}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Crossing the Ice|url=http://casandjonesy.com.au/expeditions/crossing-the-ice/| accessdate=2013-05-25}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Wilson, nå er vi framme!|url=http://gamme.no/x-blogg/entry/antarktis-2011-2012/wilsonnaerviframme|accessdate=2013-05-25|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130624120302/http://gamme.no/x-blogg/entry/antarktis-2011-2012/wilsonnaerviframme|archivedate=2013-06-24|df=}}</ref>
==Climate and day and night== {{see also|Climate of Antarctica|Midnight sun|Polar night}}
During the southern winter (March–September), the South Pole receives no sunlight at all, and from May 11 to August 1, between extended periods of twilight, it is completely dark (apart from moonlight). In the summer (September–March), the sun is continuously above the horizon and appears to move in a counter-clockwise circle. However, it is always low in the sky, reaching a maximum of 23.5° in December. Much of the sunlight that does reach the surface is reflected by the white snow. This lack of warmth from the sun, combined with the high altitude (about {{convert|2800|m|ft|sigfig=2}}), means that the South Pole has one of the coldest climates on Earth (though it is not quite the coldest; that record goes to the region in the vicinity of the [[Vostok Station]], also in Antarctica, which lies at a higher elevation).<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20090610045758/http://www.gsfc.nasa.gov/scienceques2001/20020118.htm Science question of the week], Goddard Space Flight Center.</ref> Temperatures at the South Pole are much lower than at the North Pole, primarily because the South Pole is located at altitude in the middle of a continental land mass, while the North Pole is at sea level in the middle of an ocean, which acts as a reservoir of heat.
The South Pole is at an altitude of {{convert|9300|ft|m|sigfig=2}} but feels like {{convert|11000|ft|m|sigfig=2}}.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.usap.gov/travelAndDeployment/contentHandler.cfm?id=1819|title=The USAP Portal: Science and Support in Antarctica - Course Material|website=www.usap.gov}}</ref>. Centrifugal force from the spin of the planet pulls the atmosphere toward the equator. The South Pole is colder than the [[North Pole]] because of the elevation difference.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.scientificamerican.com/article/why-is-the-south-pole-col/|title=Why is the South Pole colder than the North Pole?|publisher=}}</ref> The North Pole is a few feet from sea level.
In midsummer, as the sun reaches its maximum elevation of about 23.5 degrees, high temperatures at the South Pole in January average at {{convert|-25.9|C|F|0|abbr=on}}. As the six-month "day" wears on and the sun gets lower, temperatures drop as well: they reach {{convert|-45|C|F|0|abbr=on}} around sunset (late March) and sunrise (late September). In midwinter, the average temperature remains steady at around {{convert|-58|C|F|0|abbr=on}}. The highest temperature ever recorded at the Amundsen–Scott South Pole Station was {{convert|-12.3|C|F|1|abbr=on}} on Christmas Day, 2011,<ref>{{cite web | url=http://amrc.ssec.wisc.edu/blog/2011/12/28/preliminary-report-record-temperatures-at-south-pole-and-nearby-aws-sites/|title=Preliminary Report: Record Temperatures at South Pole (and nearby AWS sites…)|date=2011-12-28|author=Matthew A. Lazzara|accessdate=2011-12-28}}</ref> and the lowest was {{convert|-82.8|C|F|1|abbr=on}} on June 23, 1982<ref>[http://quest.nasa.gov/antarctica/background/NSF/sp-stay.html Your stay at Amundsen–Scott South Pole Station] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060202103223/http://quest.nasa.gov/antarctica/background/NSF/sp-stay.html |date=2006-02-02 }}, National Science Foundation Office of Polar Programs</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.niwa.co.nz/education-and-training/schools/resources/climate/antarctic |title=How cold is the Antarctic? |publisher=NIWA |accessdate=2012-08-13}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://icecube.wisc.edu/pole/weather|title=Antarctic Weather|accessdate=2013-05-25}}</ref> (for comparison, the lowest temperature directly recorded anywhere on earth was {{convert|-89.2|C|F|1|abbr=on}} at [[Vostok Station]] on July 21, 1983, though {{convert|-93.2|C|F|1|abbr=on}} was measured indirectly by satellite in [[East Antarctica]] between [[Dome A]] and [[Dome F]] in August 2010<ref>[http://www.nasa.gov/content/goddard/nasa-usgs-landsat-8-satellite-pinpoints-coldest-spots-on-earth/ "NASA-USGS Landsat 8 Satellite Pinpoints Coldest Spots on Earth"], ''NASA'', December 9, 2013</ref>).
The South Pole has a [[polar climate]] ([[Köppen climate classification]] ''[[Ice cap climate|EF]]''). It resembles a desert, receiving very little precipitation. Air humidity is near zero. However, high winds can cause the blowing of snowfall, and the accumulation of snow amounts to about {{convert|20|cm|in|sigfig=1|abbr=on}} per year.<ref>[https://www.nsf.gov/pubs/stis1993/opp93103/opp93103.txt Initial environmental evaluation – development of blue-ice and compacted-snow runways], National Science Foundation Office of Polar Programs, April 9, 1993</ref> The former dome seen in pictures of the Amundsen–Scott station is partially buried due to snow storms, and the entrance to the dome had to be regularly bulldozed to uncover it. More recent buildings are raised on stilts so that the snow does not build up against the sides of them.

http://www.pogodaiklimat.ru/climate2/89009.htm | title = Weather and Climate-The Climate of Amundsen–Scott | language = Russian | publisher = Weather and Climate (Погода и климат) | accessdate = 5 April 2017}}</ref> |source 2 = [[Deutscher Wetterdienst]] (precipitation 1957–1988 and sun 1978–1993),<ref name = DWD> {{cite web | url = http://www.dwd.de/DWD/klima/beratung/ak/ak_890090_kt.pdf | title = Klimatafel von Amundsen - Scott / Südpol-Station (USA) / Antarktis | work = Baseline climate means (1961-1990) from stations all over the world | publisher = Deutscher Wetterdienst | language = German | accessdate = 5 April 2017}}</ref> NOAA (snowy days data, 1961–1988)<ref name= NOAA>{{cite web | url = ftp://ftp.atdd.noaa.gov/pub/GCOS/WMO-Normals/ANTARCTICA/AM/89009.TXT | title = Amundsen–Scott Climate Normals 1961−1990 | publisher = [[National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration]] | accessdate = 5 April 2017}}</ref> |date=August 2010 }}
==Time== In most places on Earth, local time is determined by [[longitude]], such that the time of day is more-or-less synchronised to the position of the sun in the sky (for example, at midday the sun is roughly at its highest). This line of reasoning fails at the South Pole, where the sun rises and sets only once per year, and all lines of longitude, and hence all time zones, converge. There is no ''[[A priori and a posteriori|a priori]]'' reason for placing the South Pole in any particular time zone, but as a matter of practical convenience the Amundsen–Scott South Pole Station keeps [[New Zealand Time]] (UTC+12/UTC+13). This is because the US flies its resupply missions ("[[Operation Deep Freeze]]") out of [[McMurdo Station]], which is supplied from [[Christchurch]], [[New Zealand]].
==Flora and fauna== Due to its exceptionally harsh climate, there are no native resident plants or animals at the South Pole. Remarkably, though, off-course [[south polar skua]]s and [[snow petrel]]s are occasionally seen there.<ref>Mark Sabbatini, [http://antarcticsun.usap.gov/pastIssues/2002-2003/2003_01_05.pdf "Non-human life form seen at Pole"], ''The Antarctic Sun'', 5 January 2003.</ref>
In 2000 it was reported that [[microbe]]s had been detected living in the South Pole ice.<ref>[http://newsvote.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/sci/tech/827063.stm "Snow microbes found at South Pole"], BBC News, 10 July 2000</ref>
==See also== {{Portal|Antarctica}} * [[List of Antarctic expeditions]] * [[North Pole]] * [[South Pole Telescope]]
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}
==External links== {{Commons category|South Pole}} {{wikivoyage|South Pole}} * [http://www.esrl.noaa.gov/gmd/obop/spo/livecamera.html NOAA South Pole Webcam] * [http://www.adventure-antarctica.de/tag/panorama/ 360° Panoramas of the South Pole] * [http://confluence.org/confluence.php?lat=-90&lon=0&visit=1 Images of this location] are available at the [[Degree Confluence Project]] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20050905040819/http://www.cmdl.noaa.gov/gallery/SPO South Pole Photo Gallery] * [http://www.aad.gov.au/default.asp?casid=1843 Poles] by the Australian Antarctic Division * [http://antarcticsun.usap.gov/ The Antarctic Sun] – Online news source for the U.S. Antarctic Program * [http://www.bigdeadplace.com/ Big Dead Place] * [http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/sci/tech/6281839.stm UK team makes polar trek history] – BBC News article on first expedition to Pole of Inaccessibility without mechanical assistance * Listen to Ernest Shackleton describing his 1908 [http://aso.gov.au/titles/spoken-word/my-south-polar-expedition/ South Pole Expedition], and read more about the recording on [australianscreen online]. * The recording describing Shackleton's 1908 South Pole Expedition was added to the [[National Film and Sound Archive]]'s [[Sounds of Australia]] registry in 2007

{{Infobox country telephone plan | country = Cambodia | country_link = | continent = Asia | map_image = Cambodia Cold War (orthographic projection).svg | map_caption = | map_size = 200px | map_alt = | country_calling_code = +855 | international_prefix = 001, 004, 005, 006, 007, 008, 009 | trunk_prefix = | regulator = | plan_membership = | nsn_length = | dial_plan_type = | number_format = | codes_list = }}
== Land Lines == To dial a land line in [[Cambodia]] all over the country, the format is Area Code + Phone Number. The area code is 3 digits long, followed by a 6 or 7 digit phone number.
Calls made from outside Cambodia must omit the prefix 0. Therefore, to call a land line number in Phnom Penh from other countries, dialing begins with +855 23 followed by 6 or 7 digits.<ref>{{cite web|title=How to call Cambodia from the USA/Canada|url=http://www.howtocallabroad.com/cambodia/}}</ref>
== Area code == Area codes starting with 02 #[[Phnom Penh]] - 023 #[[Kandal Province|Kandal]] - 024 #[[Kampong Speu Province|Kampong Speu]] - 025 #[[Kampong Chhnang Province|Kampong Chhnang]] - 026
Area codes starting with 03 #[[Takeo Province|Takeo]] - 032 #[[Kampot Province|Kampot]] - 033 #[[Sihanoukville Province|Sihanoukville]] - 034 #[[Koh Kong Province|Koh Kong]] - 035 #[[Kep Province|Kep]] - 036
Area codes starting with 04 #[[Kampong Cham Province|Kampong Cham]] - 042 #[[Prey Veng Province|Prey Veng]] - 043 #[[Svay Rieng Province|Svay Rieng]] - 044
Area codes starting with 05 #[[Pursat Province|Pursat]] - 052 #[[Battambang Province|Battambang]] - 053 #[[Banteay Meanchey Province|Banteay Meanchey]] - 054 #[[Pailin Province|Pailin]] - 055
Area codes starting with 06 #[[Kampong Thom Province|Kampong Thom]] - 062 #[[Siem Reap Province|Siem Reap]] - 063 #[[Preah Vihear Province|Preah Vihear]] - 064 #[[Oddar Meanchey Province|Oddar Meanchey]] - 065
Area codes starting with 07 #[[Kratie Province|Kratie]] - 072 #[[Mondulkiri Province|Mondulkiri]] - 073 #[[Stung Treng Province|Stung Treng]] - 074 #[[Ratanakiri Province|Ratanakiri]] - 075
== Mobile Phones == Likewise to call mobile phones from land line or other mobile phones, domestic dialing begins a 0 followed by 8 or 9 digits.<ref>{{cite web|title=Mobile phone networks and prefixes with price links in Cambodia 2009-10|url=http://cambodia-ict.epipe.com/mobile-phone-networks-and-prefixes-with-price-links-in-cambodia-2009-10_14}}</ref>
Mobile numbers in Cambodia take the form: 0TT-AXX-XXXY.
The first two numbers after the leading 0 or 'TT' in the example above identify the operator. For example, 010 234 567 is an example of a 9 digit mobile number from [[#Network Operators|Smart]]. 088 234 5678 on the other hand is an example of a 10 digit mobile number from [[#Network Operators|Metfone]].
The 3rd digit after the leading 0 or 'A' in the example above must be between 1 and 9.<ref>{{cite web|title=NNP for Cambodia|url=http://www.itu.int/dms_pub/itu-t/oth/02/02/T02020000230001MSWE.doc}}</ref> Normally this value is between 2 and 9 which allows a value of '1' to be used for mobile phones which are roaming in Cambodia. However some operators such as Mobitel are using a '1' in this range to extend their number ranges for certain popular prefixes. For example, 012 123 4567 and 092 123 456 are valid mobile numbers in Cambodia.
'X' can take the values 0 to 9 and 'Y' is an optional extra digit which is used by some operators.
Most mobile numbers are 8 digits long (excluding the leading 0), however some operators are now using 9 digit numbers. 0882345678 is an example of a valid 9 digit mobile number.
Calls made from outside Cambodia must omit the prefix 0. Therefore, to call a mobile number in Cambodia from other countries, dialing begins with +855 1, +855 8, or +855 9 etc.
== Network Operators ==

:''For the region of Tanzania, see [[Tussock Grassland (Tanzania)]]''
'''Tussock grassland''' is a form of open [[grassland]] with [[Tussock (grass)|tussock bunchgrass]] species, that is common in some [[Temperate grasslands, savannas, and shrublands]] ecoregions of the [[Southern hemisphere]].
==Distribution== Examples are found in: [[New Zealand]] (e.g. [[New Zealand tussock grasslands]]), [[Australia]], [[Argentina]], temperate areas of southern and eastern [[Africa]], and some [[subantarctic]] islands.
It is usually typified by low rainfall and poor soils, in which few plants other than hardy [[Tussock (grass)|tussock grasses]] can flourish.
==See also== * [[New Zealand tussock grasslands]] * {{C|Bunchgrasses of Australasia}} * {{C|Bunchgrasses of South America}}
==External links== *[http://www.botany.otago.ac.nz/tussockconservation/ Otago University, Department of Biology: The Conservation Status of NZ's Indigenous Tussock Grasslands] *[http://www.teara.govt.nz/TheBush/NativePlantsAndFungi/Grasslands/1/en Te Ara:The encyclopedia of New Zealand: Tussock grasslands]
